title: Totally fun dice game
text: Totally fun dice game for camping, on the road or actually , just playing at home for fun. It was easy to understand and it is fast enough to play for older kids that they don't lose patience.

title: Love this bag
text: My husband loves to look for rocks on the beach and was always annoyed that his pockets were full of sand after. I did buy this to be more of a gag present, but he enjoyed his bag very much. The sand falls off while walking and just goes back out the bottom of the bag. We collect stones, shells and other items, perfect size and great product (a bit pricy though).

title: Fun game for a larger group
text: This is the perfect game for a party with friends, you will find out lots of funny things. This is definitely a group game, wouldn't recommend for just like a family with kids.

title: great game
text: We had a lot of fun playing the game at our camp-out, it's easy to learn and I can see this getting used over and over again. (which is not the case with all card games in our family). If you know how to play a basic solitaire you'll figure this out in minutes. Very fun!

title: OMG finally - Mario 2 and 3
text:
I was on the search for a console that plays old Mario games, specifically Mario 2 & 3, the ones I never bought as a teen and should have (and now gotta pay collectors prices if I want them). This one is it! I just pulled it out and looked for the highly anticipated Mario 2 and there it was. YAY I was so excited, pulling weeds and climbing as little Toad... there are tons more games on it, not sure if I ever go through them or play them all, but there is a huge selection. My husband found some game he played as a teen and got all nostalic too. The controllers are SNES style, so my old NES hands need to get used to the buttons being sloped, but oh well...

There are plenty of other consoles out there that are way cheaper (I'm still trying to return one of those with no mario, really a hassle) but the price of this one is totally worth it! I'm a happy clam

title: Awesome! I bought this for my husband to go ...
text: Awesome! I bought this for my husband to go camping. The board is plastic and you can just wipe it of or rinse it out, which is great when you take it to the beach or woods.

title: great starter kit
text: I bought this as a starter kit for my husbands first attempts in collecting coins. I don't think an avid coin collector would like the quality, but for easy household use and beginners, it sure does the job well. He has fun with it and he can always upgrade once he is really getting into it.

title: Batteries A does not exist it takes AA batteries.  I had to look at a competitor's web page.
text: Say the correct size batteries needed.

title: Babysitting the grandskids!
text: We loved watching the grandkids knock each other senseless.  We were able to just sit back an drink our cocktails while the boys were boys.  The little one is ruthless.  But the big one has some reach.

title: Very Cool
text: My astronaut grandson is very happy.  I mean, he looks ridiculous, but he is four.  So yeah.  He loves it.

title: Excellent Kit for young children!
text: This DIY kit exceeded all my expectations. I bought this kit for my 6-year-old grandson and he loved it painting it. Let's just say it was a great fun Thanksgiving day activity.  I highly recommend this product for anyone looking for a fun, educational project that's also pretty, to do with their child. He now proudly uses this night lamp

title: Waste of money
text: I thought these were nice quality, after a few months, all 6 have cracks and won't hold air!

title: Very Nice board.
text: Very Nice board.

title: Five Stars
text: Don't play it with your kids

title: Got two, they each lasted about a day.  They stretch out, so this is a VERY temporary toy.
text: Got two, within a day both were garbage.  The metal is SO EASILY bent that just using it normally stretches it out and god forbid you let a child touch it, it's over.  The plastic ones we've had for years, but I thought metal would be a fun upgrade.  They're just terrible.  Avoid like the plague, get the plastic ones that aren't bendable and last until they literally break.

title: Really fun for ONE DAY before the darts all started breaking. Less than a week, it's garbage.
text: Really fun.  For a day.  Then the foam arrows start falling apart.  I wish I were exaggerating.  Within a week, every dart is garbage.  Really disappointing because on Day 1, it was REALLY fun!

title: For letter recognition ONLY - boring if your kid already has that down.
text: I'd say this is only for 2-4 year olds, as the only aspect of it that's interesting is letter recognition.  If your child already knows his D from his X, this game is pretty boring.  We're returning it, it's not for kids over 3/4 that know their letters.  It has no spelling aspect at all.

title: A fantastic update to a classic game.  In addition to the electronic banking, lots of little changes to make it better.
text:
We wanted a new Life game because our old one's spinner was terrible. This one has a FANTASTIC spinner that can't jam, and the new electronic banking is really easy and fun to use. We were playing the original version once a week so I feel like I can speak from authority here - this one is loads better. It's really well-designed.

Top tip - have the banker hold onto all the credit cards. It makes no sense to keep giving them back to each player at the end of every turn.

It's a really fantastic way to update a game and they've changed so much, making it easy to play and lots of fun. My kids love it.

title: Perfect bath toy starting at any age
text: We got this when baby was around 10 months and at 19 months she still loves them every bath.  It's fun, we practice colors with them, and she loves picking them up, putting them in her mouth, playing with the net, putting them on her head, etc.  Boon is great - safe plastics with no phthalates or bad stuff.  Highly recommend this.

title: Oh how I love this sports car
text: I love this car - I bought the pink one for my daughter and we play with it all the time.  It rolls easily and looks awesome.  It's a safe plastic for her to touch and we have a lot of fun with it.

title: My gaming group asked to play it again.
text:
My gaming group doesn't always like the games I show up with. Sometimes I can't convince them to try a game, or they ask that I pull out a different game. When I offered up Iki along with a couple of others they were a bit dubious. The idea of being a merchant/shopkeeper in Edo centuries ago seemed rather mundane. But they agreed to learn the game and were soon trying to come up with strategies to maximize their points in the short 12 turns they had.

And as soon as the game was over, they asked to set up the game and play again. They enjoyed the game.

Its not perfect. There are a few timing issues that the rules don't make completely clear, and it can be a bit intimidating to teach. But once people figure out how it works the game is quite fun.

Definitely going into my regular rotation of games I bring to my group.

title: Surprisingly strategic roll and write
text:
I own several roll and write games and have played even more. They tend to be interesting, but there usually is a bit of a worry that the game will turn out to be almost completely based on luck rather than the strategy based on what you do with each roll. This one proved to be surprisingly strategic. You end up having to carefully consider how to use the roll because you can end up limiting your future opportunities with a bad choice, and the randomness of the dice definitely makes it difficult to completely mitigate luck.

Of course, it is a dice based system so luck does play a role. The dice will dictate the progress of the game. Still it received high praise from my regular gaming group, so I can say that this game is worth a play.

title: Small fast strategy game
text:
If I had any complaint its that after just 2 plays I can already see a few dominant strategies with my current gaming group. This game is definitely interesting and fun, but the limited number of places of power and cards in general limit the variability. There are a few places of power that are clearly more powerful and useful and that generates strategy focuses.

Yet, its a ton of fun, and there is replayability while people learn the full power of the various cards.

Worth it for the price.

title: Looks a bit intimidating, but a good game
text:
This game has a complex setup and appears to have a ton of rules. Its a modified version of a worker placement/action selection game where each player is trying to establish the most prestigious university through careful selection of the proper combination of students, teachers, and class upgrades. Its very much a point salad type game with many different possible choices.

I haven't gotten a ton of games in so I can't say if any one strategy is the best. The game is so complex that its difficult to bring to the table and analysis paralysis is definitely a possibility.

Still its interesting and definitely pushes the players into thinking and careful consideration of their choices. so for me, its a 4 star.

title: A good expansion to a fun game.
text:
The Zombicide series of games has been a huge moneymaker for CMON. The games take a relatively simple premise and add in solid and reasonably simple gameplay. Each mission is different enough to bring new challenges, and the way you grow your individual hero or heroes turns the game into a unique experience each time.

It is not an inexpensive game due to the number of miniatures in the box, but if you have been enjoying these, adding this to your Zombicide 2nd Edition main box is not a bad thing. This adds some great missions to the game with a new set of maps and characters.

title: Big and complex game, but also straightforward
text:
There was so much for me to like with this game. It has a depth few games have, with a lot of different strategies that could work due to the number of options despite the fact that a player only has 6 different options for what action to take each turn.

I've heard this described as Zoo Tycoon the board game, and it fits that. Will you try to fill your zoo with appealing animals and impress everyone that way? Or will you try to build up your conservation bonafides and get your zoo declared the best for its efforts? Or can you find a new path between the extremes?

Its definitely not easy to learn. My first game included one person who had played before, one very experienced gamer and two relatively newer gamers. The score quickly showed that the experienced players built a huge lead and turned the score into a race. The other two enjoyed the game, but both admitted that the complexity of the options had slowed their progress.

This is not for those who can get analysis paralysis, but it is a great game and I expect it to become a regular game in my rotation of what I bring to the table.

title: I like the character and this FUNKO is nice.
text: I don't care for many of the Funko dolls, but I liked this one.  I can't say much more than that really.

title: I like this one
text: I don't care for many of the Funko dolls, but I liked this one.  I can't say much more than that really.

title: Interesting, but I don't think it adds much.
text:
Expansions to games need to add something. It needs to make the game more dynamic and interesting without feeling like it added complexity needlessly. And honestly this expansion seems to have mostly been a way to add complexity.

And worse, I see this as making a runaway game worse. Someone who gets ahead will likely be able to use the bonuses from alchemy to get even more ahead. (I haven't played in a game where its made a difference, but I've only used it once.)

I enjoy the basic Quacks, but honestly I don't expect that I'll be bringing this expansion out often. It just added another thing to track without making the game more fun.

title: Not for children, but I like the art.
text: Honestly this kind of playmat is hard to judge overall.  There are some where the artwork doesn't stick well to the pad, but that is rare and definitely not a problem in this case.  After that, the only question is if you like the art, and I'll admit to being the kind of person who does appreciate this kind of art.  Its not for children and some people will find it offensive, but if you can appreciate this kind of art, it definitely will be a playmat you like.

title: Simple rules, but lots of strategy.
text:
Card drafting mechanics are always a challenge, and the way Elysium works with turns and the requirement to purchase/draft 3 cards and 1 "quest" every round is one that places a huge level of strategy into the game. Do you go for the card you really want, even if it will limit your choices later, or do you skip it to take a different option and hope that its still available when you get another opportunity.

And that can be a perilous challenge. You have to predict your opponents and might not guess correctly. I've had a couple of times where I was unable to make a legal move and had to accept the penalty because I drafted poorly.

Not a really deep game, but good fun and one that my local game group gave a huge thumbs up for.

title: Good fun in a fast paced game.
text:
Its not the most complex of games, but that's too its benefit as its easy to learn and plays quickly. There are still plenty of strategic opportunities as deciding to put in herbivores over carnivores and how many of each type to have makes a considerable difference in the number of deaths and the overall score of the park.

Definitely one of the games that I have felt rewarded for purchasing.

title: Doesn't add a lot, but what it does add works.
text:
The Quacks of Quedlinberg is a fun "press your luck" game where you have to decide if you want to keep pulling chips from your bag trying to make a slightly more powerful potion, but pulling too many of the wrong chips causes you to lose out on the full bonus. Luck does play a surprising amount of a role, but its a great game.

The Herb Witches expansion adds one new ingredient as well as 3 herb witches that can each be called on once per game to provide a benefit.

It adds quite a bit of strategy. Timing the use of the herb witches can provide a huge boost to your chances, but poor timing might limit how much you get. And the press your luck element remains.

My gaming group likes this game.

title: Just a variant to the original Rhino for 40K, but nice
text:
This is not a huge change to the standard Rhino. There is a new sprue that adds the icons and armor for the Adepta Sororitas, but otherwise this is a standard Rhino. Its easy to assemble and build and has nice large details that take paint well.

Good figure even if the Rhino is not exactly a game changer in battle.

title: Good, but the figures aren't modular
text:
These models reminded me of the old pewter models that Games Workshop once made. They are nicely modeled, but this set doesn't have a lot of different pieces so you can't make truly individualized figures easily. I believe there is another kit with the Escher Weapons you can purchase.

That would be my only complaint, but outside that, this is a very good set.

title: simple and solid
text:
I had a fight gauge that had been made from the pressed wood that is often used by companies like Broken Token for their box fillers. It worked rather well, but I lost it and needed a replacement.

This is a great replacement. its well made with clear markings that make it easy to use. My only complaint would be the price as it is a bit pricy for what it is.

Still if you play a lot of Warhammer, this would be something that will improve taking close measurements within your game.

title: Biggest one I've tried.
text:
I have a purchased quite a few card cases as I'm trying to organize a huge collection of various kinds of cards. This case is the largest I've purchased as it contains 4 build in rows, against the 2 or 3 of the smaller ones I own. However, it lacks the webbing in the lid that some cases have to allow the storage of commonly used items (rulebooks, tokens, etc.)

Still its great for holding large numbers of cards and I do recommend it for someone who needs to keep many low value, but wanted cards.

title: Good expansion.
text: This is not a huge expansion, but it adds elements that improve the game.  There are new locations, characters and even the pieces required to add a fifth player.  If you enjoy the original game, this is a solid upgrade.

title: Complex, and tends to include a lot of "filing" but interesting
text:
I've heard that some people complain a bit about the amount of "filing" in this game. The base game includes hundreds of small square cards that contain all of the map locations and notes of what is happening. Keeping these in order and placing the correct ones does take a bit of work.

However, the reason for all the filing does slowly come out. This is a deep game where a curse has been placed on your characters and you are attempting to solve it. The cards themselves are your timer as once they run out the game will end if a certain card is drawn once you reshuffle the discard pile.

The game is not forgiving. You need to work together, and work fast to get through the adventure as quickly as possible. Yet, rushing increases the odds of failure for each skill check.

Its not for everyone, and I will admit that I hesitate to bring it out unless i know the group I'm going to show it to are going to be interested. But with the right group its a great game.

title: Looks complex, but has a great flow.
text:
When you first look at this game it seems like it will be very complex, but once you start playing you can see that the options all make sense. This is a very tactical game where you want to plan ahead and then make careful plays.

Its exactly the type of game I love.

title: Just a pad of special gamesheets and a few rule changes
text:
The summer expansion offered a need to deliver ice cream to houses as you built the perfect sub-division. Now its winter and you have to adjust your building to make sure you have long strings of consecutive numbers as these houses will be putting out holiday lights which will increase your score.

Its a time change to the rules, but adds clear new challenges as now you have to be more careful with house numbers as you build.

Of course this comes with 3 new goal cards involving attempts to get a certain number of consecutive numbers on a street in order to gain additional points.

I like this game. Its simple, quick and fun, and this expansion doesn't try too hard to change a winning formula.

title: Nice figures for a fun army
text:
Its hard to really say much about these. Its a box of plastic sprues that can eventually make 5 jetpack wearing warriors of the Adepta Sororitas for Warhammer 40K. There are more than a few options since you can either arm them with dual pistols as Seraphim or give them one pistol and a power sword and make them Zephyrim. Both types of squads have their uses on the battlefield and you can mix/match the arms legs to make every character just a bit different.

If you like the idea of "Nuns with Guns" these might fit your army. I find that I like this kind of unit, so I'm happy to add another squad to my slowly developing force that will be fighting to protect the 40th Millennium.

title: Love the art
text: It has great art and looks to be solidly made.  These items are good if you like the art and since i like the art, its definitely what I want.

title: A great game with solid rules
text:
Game Workshop is taking quite a bit of honestly deserved criticism for some recent actions. That doesn't change the fact that they created and maintain a surprisingly dynamic universe and several games that allow people to adventure into these places. This core book is the foundation for the rules to the original game, updated to streamline game play.

Its worth the money for anyone who loves the idea of battling in the future with small squads. My only complaint has always been how much the game rewards having certain named figures in your army. But you can always choose to leave them out.

title: Great for holding a large number of cards
text: I have a huge collection of CCGs that I'm trying to organize.  This case has proved to be the perfect way to hold a large number of cards securely.  There isn't much more I can really say.  I am impressed with the size of the case for the cost.  Beyond that, it is not much different from the many others available.

title: Very nice construction, but "pick foam" cuts weren't very good.
text:
I love the design and the form. The only issue I discovered was that the "pick foam" sections were not deeply die cut. I had to use an exacto knife to cut out the pockets I wanted.

Other than that, it is an excellent way to protect your tabletop army.

title: Good engine building game with options
text:
I can't really say too much about this game that you can't find elsewhere. Its a rather imaginative engine building game where you make selections that in theory will pay greater dividends in the future while trying to score the most points based on completing tasks.

This isn't a new mechanic, although some of the methods of building your engine are not commonly found, so they do offer some new mental challenges.

Overall, this is a nice game with a good aesthetic. I can't speak to the replayability, but it definitely is one to bring out with those that like the level of challenge offered her.

title: More races for our Encounter in Space
text:
Cosmic Encounter is a simple game that can be a ton of fun with a good group of people. This expansion adds more races to the mix, which obviously means that there are new ways to change the rules and offer new possibilities.

And that is where this game is fun. It's not a deep strategy game where you have to think hard about what you are doing. You draw a card to find out who you will attack, try to coax others into allying with you, and then using your special abilities see what happens in the attack. Then its the next person's turn.

But that's what makes this a great game for groups to while away some time. This adds new powers, which is always good to keep the game fresh. I expect to eventually get all the expansions. They're worth it.

title: Smaller than I expected, but good for 25mm figures
text:
I actually thought this was larger, as I own a number of cases that work for 25mm figures, but needed something that would hold 40mm figures. However, when this arrived I quickly discovered that its sized for 30 figures with 25mm bases.

For that its an excellent case, with a compact size that will make it easy to carry and plenty of padding to protect your figures in transit.

Good value for the money, but its only for smaller figures. Look elsewhere if you have larger figures to protect.

title: Complex worker placement, but maintains the fun
text:
Worker Placement games tend to ride in that strange space between too simple and predictable and too complex and causing analysis paralysis. The River falls in the middle. Its not so simple that people can rightly complain, but at the same time there is a limited number of options and you shouldn't end up waiting too long for someone to make a decision and act.

Beyond that its a fairly straight-forward point scoring game where the person who manages to get the best "engine" going will win.

I like these, but its definitely a "your mileage may vary" situation. If you don't like worker placement type games, this is not for you.

title: Solid card case
text:
I decided that I was going to start organizing a lot of my old CCGs and other games this year and one thing I've found I need is better card cases than the old cardboard ones that cluttered my closets. This is the third design I've ordered from Amazon, and honestly, its probably the best of the three (although not perfect).

The case itself is nicely sturdy with a nicely padded interior. The dividers are solidly made, and flexible enough to be easy to install and remove. The case lid does have webbing set up as a pouch which can hold loose items like rulebooks, dice, munchkin level counters, etc.

This is a good case to get if you need the ability to hold a large number of cards and don't want to take up too much space.

title: Just adds complexity to an already too complex game
text:
I have a bit of a love/hate relationship with this game. I really like the idea and the overall worker placement gameplay. There are multiple ways to win and several nice mechanics that make the game a challenge.

Unfortunately, this is a game that you absolutely can't play with anyone who has a habit of overanalyzing their own play. I've had games where one person's turn can end up taking 3-4 minutes every time they get to move while the rest of the people at the table just sit and watch. It is just not a good game for certain types of players.

The Festival of Masks adds a number of new cards in teh form of the masks and new scoring options based off the masks. That by itself isn't a huge change, but in a game with a point salad scoring that is already prone to causing analysis paralysis, its not a good addition. Expect this to add time to the play without really offering a huge improvement to the overall experience.

title: Others are better
text:
I purchased this card case after a different brand was not available when I was looking. And while this is one of the least expensive variants, I found that I was disappointed by the lack of a pouch in the lid to hold large items. The box also seemed a bit smaller than others as cards in sleeves caused the lid to be nearly impossible to close, while other cases I have have not had an issue with closing over sleeved cards.

Its decent, but other ones are much better.

title: Your basic line troops for the Daughters of Khaine
text:
This box can make 10 witch aelves or 10 sisters of slaughter. The supplied instructions shows with pieces fit together to make either as you assemble the figures. It's a lot of information, but the sprues do have identification numbers imprinted to make it easier to figure out which pieces go together.

The box also includes a sheet of transfers you can add to things like the battle standard to give your army a bit of detail. Its simple, but nice to see..

The big issue most will have is the price. This is 10 figures and the MSRP makes it so its $6.00 per plastic figurine, and that's without paint, glue or the time involved in assembly. But these are your basic line troops for the Daughters, and you will need them to assemble most armies of this faction. (You can have an army general allowing medusae to be your line troops, but they are even more expensive.)

Then again, no one ever said Warhammer was an inexpensive hobby. If you like the army, go for it. I'd just recommend at least reviewing the army codex first so you have an idea what you are getting into, or if your local game shop has resumed holding matches, go and talk to players to get an idea of what faction might be right for you.

title: Doesn't add much to the game
text: This box adds a lot of cards to the set, but the rules say that when you use this set you are to remove cards from the original game and replace them with cards from this set.  So while you do get some new strategies and plays, it doesn't feel like a really impactful change overall.  The new cards offer a few new tricks, but they are variants on plays from the first game.  I just didn't see anything major changing with this expansion.  its nice, but I want my expansions to offer more.

title: Good game, but luck does play a role
text:
I've liked this game for a long time. It's an imaginative strategy game where you are trying to build a space empire, but the powers you are going to use are randomized by dice that you will roll at the start of each turn and then spend for actions.

Honestly, I have never been as good at this game as I'd like. I haven't played enough to know all the nuances of the game, so I tend to struggle to get the engine started and running early. And this is definitely an "engine-building" game where the actions you take build on all actions you took in previous turns. Knowing which improvements work together and what strategies you want to play to purchase the best dice takes time.

It is definitely a fun game with a solid learning curve. I don't think its an every session type of game, but its worth bringing out occasionally.

title: Costly for just 2 figures, but Morathi makes the Daughters work
text:
This is a massive box for two figures. One is Morathi's humanoid form and the other is the massive naga/gorgon she can morph into (and which she split into during the recent Morathi Codex storyline.) As a unit for Age of Sigmar she's probably one of the more important army generals.

That said, as far as I'm concerned the best part of this box was that there is an included manual showing how to put the figures together and they identify each component by a number (which can be found on the plastic sprues). I haven't started assembling these two, but I know it will be easier thanks to that one small item.

I look forward to putting these on a tabletop sometime in 2021 when my local stores start holding games again.

title: More deck building than card drafting and falls a bit short
text:
This is a very simple game that claims to be card "drafting", but plays more like a deck builder where you have a bit more control over which resources will be available every turn. (Partly because your hand/deck of cards is small.)

Its not a bad game, and the artwork is definitely high quality, but the overall gameplay does not lend itself to repeated play. This is a filler game that once explained to others will play very quickly.

I give it 3 stars. Its not bad, but it won't be at the top of my playlist in the future.

title: game has a flaw in the rules.
text:
Its an interesting game with some rather fun challenges, but there was a flaw in the rules. One of the lion prides gets a boost to the "Roar" ability that can be abused badly. it unbalances the game and can make it much less fun than it should be.

Other than that, its a nice game with an interesting premise, but sadly, I have to say either find a good house rule to limit the power of the one pride or ban them if you want everyone to enjoy playing.

title: Solid, although the straps are a bit tricky at first
text:
I got this to help control the wandering CCG cards I have lying around. I thought that something like this would provide a great way to carry a large number of cards neatly. The case is definitely that, and I'm quite happy to have found it.

My only comment would be the seperation straps. They are velcro and can be a bit difficult to position exactly where you want them as they are not as stiff as I expected, and they shift as you try to get the hooks to engage. But they do work nicely once they are attached.

I like it and will probably get more to coordinate other cards I have lying around.

title: Not a simple game, but fun
text:
Clank is a mix of a press-your-luck game with the dungeon delving combined with a deck-building mechanic. It results in an interesting if someone complex game that can be a ton of fun. I'd say my biggest complaints were just how little came in the base game. I expected more cards and more possibilities, but there are a limit on the cards in the base game, indicating that you'll run into problems with replayability eventually.

But its a fine game. I just now feel that other games offer better value.

title: Much better than the racing version
text:
This game is pretty simple. Each time you take the dice you'll basically be playing nine holes of golf. The dice are set up with 2 for par 3 holes, 2 for par 5, and the remaining 5 for par four holes. When you start you'll roll all 9 dice. You must keep at least one, but can reroll all the others, and you continue to reroll until you've set aside all 9 dice at which point you score the dice.

Its that simple. Lowest score over X number of holes wins (the game suggests playing 8 rounds to simulate a full 4 day golf tournament).

Fun, portable and very easy to play. It does have the downside of basically being completely random, and in someways its a variation on Yahtzee, but its well themed. If you want a good dice game for trips and don't want Yahtzee, this is a good one to choose.

title: Mille Bornes with dice?
text:
I love the old Mille Bornes racing card game. This dice game felt a bit like that, but with extra dice that get rolled only if certain combinations come up on the regularly rolled dice.

The concept is good, but the play is a bit awkward and takes me out of the zen of playing.

If you want one of these, try the golf game first. Its a much better game.

title: great way to protect your dice and table
text:
I can't tell anyone the number of times a dice I rolled managed to fall to the floor. These stiff hexagons are the perfect way to set up a place to roll dice without giving them space to tumble onto the floor.

Not much more to say, but I cna say mine will be used quite a bit in the future.

title: simple, fast.  But I can't complain about the artwork
text:
Or can I? Actually the artwork is extremely repetitive. Yes, its cute girls in bikinis, but that shouldn't be a basis for rating a game.

Strangely enough, the game definitely felt like it lacked a little. Its a 2 person game that's designed to be easy and light, which are good points, but there isn't much depth and I prefer games that generate social interaction. This game is a decent filler when your 3rd and 4th players haven't arrived, but I just didn't find it to be amazing.

title: I like these.
text:
Its hard to say a lot about these. I liked this series and I like this kind of action figure, but I don't "play" with them. They usually end up sitting on a shelf, sometimes in their original box.

But I like them and the Max Factory ones are well made and detailed. Worth it if you like collecting.

title: easy to get the basics.  Good family game
text:
This was my first "roll and write" or in this case "turn cards and write" game. And honestly I was surprised by how simple this is to teach, but how fun to play. This is the kind of game where I can show it to my parents and definitely get them to try it.

My only complaint would be that unless you spend the money to get the dry erase boards, you will use up the pad eventually. I already know that I'll probably be making copies to avoid that problem for now.

title: Fun little toy
text: Noise, lights, playful antics, works on a desk.  Not much more to say.

title: Great and simple fun
text: It's fun having one of these.  My girlfriend says its a "pet" you can turn off when you don't want it around, and that almost fits.  Great fun to play with.

title: Fun game that takes little time
text:
This is a great game in that while there is a bit of randomness, overall the game is completely in the hands of hte players. They decide how far to move nad what to do when they land on a space. Those choices can win them the game or lose it. They want know until the end, as players can have secret goals.

The artwork is stunning and the game sets up and plays in under an hour even with new players or those prone to analysis paralysis.

One of my favorites, which is why I finally purchased it and the expansions.

title: LIttle changes bring great fun
text:
The original game is great. It looks complex and scary, but once you get started you realize that the concepts are simple but at the same time the flexibility the player has makes it look complex. The choices you have definitely turn out to be far more interesting than you might expect.

This expansion helps add more options, but ones that only improve the amount of options and their effects. THere is now a huge benefit in bidding just 1-2 tokens as the remainder can still produce something for your theater and play.

This is a great game and the expansion only offered more fun.

title: Doesn't fix what's broken
text:
This game has some major flaws, primarily in the way that you gain new cards and the fact that the monster attacks are so random. This expansion does add the Kraken as a timed monster, but little more. The villain guests and their effects are even less exciting.

The game is interesting, but I found that this expansion felt very underwhelming.

title: Classic that is still around for a reason
text:
I first tried playing this game mroe than 20 years ago, and I remember it to this day.

There is a reason that people call something a classic. It usually has an elegance and simplicity that makes it easy to grasp and yet endures as more flashy offerings fade quickly. Cosmic Encounter is just such a classic. Its a very simple game with a simple premise and rules, but then adds on a system to break those same rules. It makes for an infinitely replayable game that can be taught quickly and is almost always fun. (I've run into a few jerks playing, which tends ot make the game frustrating, but that's the players, not the game causing it.)

Definitely worth the purchase. I'm just surprised it took me this long to obtain a copy myself.

title: This game has some flaws, but its fun
text:
Deck building games tend to have one huge flaw, they play a bit too much like solitaire with limited interaction between players. Heart of Crown is a neat game with a simple premise, but definitely suffers a bit due to the interaction problem.

That said, this expansion helps keep a solid game going and adds a bit more replayability since it adds additional cards that can be swapped in when the game is setup. I find that this is an expansion that will get some use.

title: There is a reason this game is no longer produced
text:
The figures are nice, the game has potential, but its more complex than it needs to be and finding opponents is difficult. It's nice to have if you play a lot of games, but there is no instance where this is a good introductory game.

It's fun, but there are much better games available. I give this 3 stars.

title: Just not a compelling game.
text: Honestly, after looking at the rules, this seems to be nothing more or less than any of the earlier "heroclix" games I've tried over the years.  The game is somewhat fun, but not my favorite.  Still it can be good for a quick series of games on a lazy afternoon.

title: A really fun game.
text:
This one was a bit of a "wow" when I got it. It's a good simple deck-building games with enough of a spin on the genre to generate new strategies and a fair amount of open interaction. This isn't like dominion where the score is hidden in the deck. Here you know everyone's score and how close they are to winning. You also have to carefully play your cards as some don't allow the endless plays that can be pulled off in other games of this genre.

Great fun and amazing artwork.

title: Good, simple expansion.
text: I like this game, its a bit more complex than many other "deck-building" games, but retains the overall simplicity that makes these games easy to teach and fun to play.  This expansion doesn't add a huge amount, but does increase the number of options which is always a good thing with this genre.

title: Great twist on fantasy combat.
text:
I tried this one around Christmas after running into someone with it at a Tuesday night gaming night at my local game shop. It was a lot of fun, although the learning curve is extremely steep at first and the setup took longer than you might expect. However, once you get through the first few rounds and figure out how to handle combat, its a ton of fun. The tactics are rather detailed and deep and there is a huge amount of "give and take" in the play as you have to decide when to burn a card and when to rest to refill your hand, with the knowledge that every card you don't play before resting is a move you have lost and brings you closer to exhaustion.

Since then I have gone out and purchased the game. It looks very intimidating at first, but its so worth playing. I definitely recommend this to anyone who likes tactic combat in a fantasy world.

title: Figma puts a lot of effort into making these.
text: I don't know why, but I really like these figures.  This one is definitely a product of Figma's great care in putting together an action figure.  In addition to the configuration shown in the pictures, this figure comes with three interchangeable faces, a bowl of rice for her left hand, and chopsticks for her right.  And even some round balls that look like meatballs.  It is a great way to bring out the character of Akagi from the series.

title: Really like this game.
text:
I like the Teen Titans as characters and I found that I really like this edition of the DC Comics Deck-building game. The characters have good skills that make each one play differently, but in a fun way. The locations add a bit of strategy to the play, and the villains are difficult, but not overwhelming like ones from the crisis expansion can be. I'd recommend this or the full base game if you want to start collecting this.

I will note that this game plays very similar to Ascension in some ways, and while you are playing a hero working to defeat a super villain, there isn't a lot of teamwork and you don't end up with a deck themed to your hero unless you purchase cards in that manner. It thins the theme a bit. But overall, I still like this game, its fun and can be played quickly by most players.

title: Not my favorite expansion.
text:
I hate to admit that while I like this game overall, this expansion was a bit underwhelming for me. I didn't know any of the heroes, and the time-travel ability on some cards can get tricky to use during a game.

It was still interesting to add to my collection, but I expect people will prefer to use other heroes and cards when playing.

title: Very good expansion, and nice way to purchase multiple packs.
text:
It's hard to figure out if I'm supposed to review the game itself (I've reviewed it many times and do recommend it), or what you are getting here which is 8 of the Tomb of Annihilation draft packs.

This is a fairly good way to purchase these draft packs. You won't get all the rares and definitely not all the super rares (although I understand you are guaranteed one super rare out of the 16 rares/super rares you'll find in the 8 boxes.).

The nice thing is that even though each box has 12 creature cards and 2 dice per card, there are enough different creatures/traps/items that there shouldn't be a huge amount of wasted dice since you can't use more than 4 of any one die in a game. You will find that you do get at least some duplicates though, just due to the number of cards.

I really like this game overall and the cards/dice here are fun to use. This was an expansion I was very happy to purchase a large number of packs from

title: I was a bit underwhelmed by this expansion
text: I like the Dice Masters game, its simple, its easy to teach and/or play and its a lot of fun.  Unfortunately I was a bit disappointed in this expansion pack.  I just didn't find the cards to be ones that I expect to play often.  I can't say they are terrible, but I just don't expect them to end up in my regular rotation.

title: Good game, not my favorite expansion.
text:
I put this at 3 stars not because I don't like the game. I really like the game overall. My disappointment was with the set of heroes in this expansion. I knew that it was going to include some heroes that I am not a huge fan of, but when I opened the box and started organizing I realized that I would not be enthusiastic about using more than 2/3 of the heroes in this expansion.

The game itself is very fun to play, although I do believe that the enjoyment is partly driven by if you like the heroes you have chosen. Which is why I could only give this expansion 3 stars, there just weren't enough heroes I like to make this an expansion I expect to have as part of the regular rotation.

title: Not the best expansion I've ever seen, but good.
text:
My biggest warning here would be just how small these crossover packs are. You do get 7 new heroes and a complete set of super villains to add to the game. However, there are only a small number of new cards to add to the deck, which surprised me a bit.

The heroes are interesting, but perhaps not well known except to dedicated comic fans. It is nice to see the addition of the new set of villains.

It's still a good addition to a fun game.

title: Good game
text:
This game plays very similar to Ascension, which is a deck-building game I first learned more than a year ago. Is not perfect, but I find it interesting and fun.

I do agree with people who say that the Marvel Legendary deck-building game is a bit better overall, but I enjoy this game and find it an interesting challenge.

title: Passable Expansion.
text:
This expansion adds a few things to the Dark Tales game. The main one is "balls" which occur after three cards have been discarded. At that point players pair up the male and female characters they have in play and obtain victory points. The new cards from this expansion provide characters who give bonus points during these balls, although any cards work.

It's interesting as are the new items, but nothing here is a huge game-changing addition. And I think some of the other expansions offer more. This is just... passable.

title: like the ones found in any starter deck
text:
This proved to be an interesting change in the way to purchase Dice masters. Previously you could either purchase a starter with set dice or "boosters" that would contain 2 dice and 2 cards. These packs have 14 cards and 24 dice. 2 cards are action cards, like the ones found in any starter deck. You then find 12 of the usual character cards and each card gets 2 dice. The cards here are mixed 5-7 common, 3-5 uncommon and 2 rare/super rare.

If you like the game and have at least one starter set, these packs are a nice way to add to your collection. you are guaranteed 2 dice for any cards, and the cards themselves are a nice mix of attacking and defending dice with the new traps being surprisingly versatile and interesting.

My only complaint would be the price. Boosters usually go for $0.99 for 2 dice. These new packs here shouldn't be more than $14 or so, and the seller I found was asking more, but he was also the only one selling, leaving me little choice at the time.

title: Solid figure
text:
I enjoy having this kind of action figure. With this purchase I now have several that are characters from Strike Witches. This was my first model from this manufacturer, but the quality I expected was there. This one might not have the number of additional pieces of other manufacturers, but the figure is clear with good detail.

I'm happy with this purchase

title: Another well made figurine
text: I don't purchase many of these due to the high cost, but every time I have, they have proven to be excellent.  This one was no exception.  It came with detailed pieces and the usual solid design and construction I have come to expect from the manufacturer.

title: Fun game
text:
I enjoy playing dicemasters. yes its just Quarriors with Marvel or DC or D&D artwork, and the rules turn it into a strange merger of deck building and Magic the Gathering, but using dice. However, the game is fun.

The Batman expansion was an interesting one with the new feature that some cards can change their allegiance. The card is two sided and can be flipped every turn based on which faction you want to be part of. It's an interesting dynamic and I'll probably try to make use of it someday soon.

title: Fun, but not deep worker placement.
text:
The idea is cute, the mechanics are not simple, but do not require a degree in astrophysics to understand, and the game is naturally designed to move forward quickly.

I think the biggest flaws are the fact that the game is a bit rigid in a way. The monsters, cage addons, festivals and customers do change, but those are largely cosmetic. You often end up committed to a path in the first 2 turns and then praying that you can get the right results to allow your plan to be the victorious one.

Still, its a fun worker placement game with a great and offbeat theme. I can definitely recommend this one

title: Better than some expansions.
text:
It's a surprisingly simple expansion, adding only a few options to a game that already had quite a few. But the options do add a good amount of strategy to the game and that is something I always prefer.

I'd recommend playing without this first, to get used to the rules and especially the scoring, but after that adding this shouldn't add any time to the game itself.

title: Great party game
text:
This game is fun! It's simple, requires one to think ahead, but also for the players to wheel and deal, which means there is a lot of interaction with the other players.

It's not even super complex although it would take a while for most children to pick up due to some of the tricks in the rules.

Still a great game to bring out at parties since it requires little setup and can be played by any adult after only a brief description of play.

title: Fun party game for quick thinkers who love to talk.
text:
This is an amazing game, both in the concept and then in the play itself.

The first thing is that this is a game which will challenge your imagination. The game plays with one person taking on the role of "dark overlord". They will start and end each round. they start it by looking at one of the other players and basically asking why their most recent plot failed.

But after that the imagination takes over. The minions goal is to avoid the blame. They do this by playing hint and action cards. Hint cards give them a hint as to what their excuse is for the failure. Perhaps they ran into a monster (like "the puppy", perhaps they ended up at the wrong location "the lonely tower" or even a wild event happened "the whirlwind") the player will use the hint to start telling a story as to why the group failed. He will also play a "pass the buck" action card to move the blame to another player.

Players can insert themselves into the process by playing "freeze" actions, This allows them to say "Actually Dark Overlord, that statement is not quite true" and to change it slightly forcing the minion currently being grilled to modify their tale.

It's all about storytelling and thinking quickly. Failure to respond promptly is one of the failures that allows the Dark Overlord to command for silence and give the minion a "withering look" When one player gets 3 withering looks the game ends. Other failures can be for not having a pass the buck card, boring the dark overlord or not using the information on the hint card well enough.

There is a variant of the game which uses some additional symbols on the cards to make the storytelling a bit less a part of the game, but they don't take away from the idea that this is a fun, frantic game where the goal is to not be the odd minion out when the Dark Overlord decides someone must pay for the failure.

It's a great party game with people who enjoy storytelling and can think quick on their feet. But it does require some people. The game says 3-8 players, but less than 5 will almost always turn the game into a beatdown on one poor minion.

title: Fun worker placement, no knowledge of Dungeons and Dragons required.
text:
This is a worker placement game, which means that it is a lot more strategic than many people realize. It has some randomizers in that everything is presented through shuffled decks of cards (intrigues, quests and buildings) and that randomness can make what seems like a great strategy ultimately fail when the quest you need doesn't show up.

I think I like this a bit more than Stone Age. Lords of Waterdeep offers a lot more strategy than other worker placement games thanks to the quests since the players have some ability to choose which quests to undertake. Also controlling which building gets built can have a huge effect on the outcome as the buildings tend to be far more powerful than the base locations that are available at the start of the game.

This game isn't for everyone, but a love and knowledge of Dungeons and Dragons is not required (it adds flavor only). The key here is a patient and strategic mind and a willingness to use up 1-2 hours plotting your success while hopefully interfering just enough in the plans of the other players to come out on top at the end.

title: Average expansion to an average game.
text:
The addition of solitare rules to Race for the Galaxy is nice. That part of this expansion clearly received a good deal of attention. The new bonuses will also add just a bit to the game, although with the small number of new cards if you only have this and the original game you'll find that the usual strategies are all that work.

Overall, I find Race for the Galaxy to be a fun, quick if largely luck based game and this expansion did nothing to change that. The new starting planets and additional phase cards designed to allow an additional player are nice, but the overall strategic challenge is still lacking.

title: Nice way to make a game interesting
text:
This game is simple and twisted. After all who would deliberately try to make the people under their care miserable, but that's the goal here.

As others have posted and the game eve points out the premise is simple. You start with 5 members of a family and the goal is to have them die miserable and alone. You can do that by having them "Pursued by Poodles" or a host of other funny but twisted happenings until you finally play an "Untimely Death" and end their misery. The player who manages to have his family die the most miserable, wins.

the mechanics are simple. The cards are see through, with scoring cards having up to three circles containing a value on the left side of the card. Cards are played by placing them over the poor unfortunate soul being afflicted or occasionally blessed (giving a positive score to an opposing players family member. When there are no living members of any family, the visible scoring circles are added up to determine the victor.

Its simple and fun, but you do need people who like to tell tales and will actually read the card titles. If you play with someone who isn't into that, the game can be a bit less fun.

title: Tactical resource gathering game.
text:
This is a very complex and detailed game. It's not for children and it requires that the people playing are ready to spend several hours dealing with the complexities of the system.

At the same time, its a fun game. There are no dice which would be used to randomize events. The game is affected by your play and that of your opponents.

Overall, this is a resource allocation game. You start with two "meeples", who are effectively workers on you farm. Each turn you can send them out to collect resources or to perform special actions that build additional space or activate a special card. After certain turns you have to "feed" your meeples giving up some resources you had previously collected. In the end points are scored based on how big of a home and farm you have grown over the course of the game. The game winner is the one who manages to plan ahead and use his meeples wisely.

Of course, the challenge is to collect the resources at the right times. Most stocks grow if no one collects them that turn, so there is a bit of tactically plotting. Do you send someone to collect the small amount of wood this turn, or do you let it go and hope no one claims it. All of the resources play out this way, you have to decide which is going to be the most value at that time.

If you can find people willing to put the time in, this Is an excellent game.

title: Well thought out game.
text:
THis is a surprisingly simple game. There are a very small number of cards. You start by dealing every player one card, then each player will draw one card and play/discard a card until there are no more to draw. The player still actively playing and with the highest value card when the deck runs out of cards wins the round.

Of course some cards have special powers, which adds a tactical element. Do you think your knight is of higher value than another persons hidden card. Do you hang on to a high value card when your opponent might have a card with the power to knock you out of the round if he plays it?

Simple concern, well executed. It's not a game that takes hours, but a good starter game hwen you are setting up for an evenings gaming.

title: Mind the small print
text:
This deck building game is a definitely a nice add to the genre. Most games of this genre especially the order ones like Dominion limit the purchasable cards to ten different ones each in their own stack. Kanzume Goddess changes that by dividing all of the purchasable cards into six random stacks. This means that on your turn the cards you can purchase will change depending on which stacks your opponent acts upon during his turn.

The game play is also different as some cards have an attack value which is used to harm your opponent. The game ends when a player reaches zero health.

Great fun, and much more interactive than Dominion.

My only negative was the text on the cards. I have good vision and I still found that I needed a magnifying glass in order to read the cards. From what I can tell these are printed in 5 point font. Once you get to know the cards, it isn't as important, but for a first time player I'm sure there will be a bit of "what does this card do?" going on.

Otherwise, its a good game, with nice mechanics, pleasing artwork and a theme which encourages interaction during play.

title: Delightfully twisted deck building game
text:
Many deck building games play a bit like solitaire where what you do has little to no effect on the other players. The game immediately breaks that mold as you not only purchase cards to improve your own deck, but are purchasing cards to send to another players deck. Strategies that were part of other deck building games are useless here as you don't have the same level of control.

The game itself is very simple and staightforward. Cards produce 2 forms of "gold" (friendship and nightmare). Friendship purchases schoolgirls who go into your own deck to help fight against the chthonic teachers of the school. Nightmare purchases teachers who go into the deck of the player on your left and will be torturing his students until madness overtakes him and he loses the game. At least he does if you haven't gone mad first.

The battles are equally simple. Teachers have scores for how tough they are and how frightening they are while the girls have scores for how strong they are at defeating teachers. Sanity is lost if the teachers win the battle during a players turn.

And that is how it works. deckbuilding becomes a balancing act of gathering the cards that produce the most nightmarish power to send evil teachers to your opponent while supplying enough friendship to purchase the tougher schoolgirls to battle the nightmares that find their way into your deck. Unlike other deckbuilding games the actions of your opponents now directly affect you and mold your strategies.

The game itself isn't hte highest quality. The cards feel a bit flimsy and the artwork is a bit more cartoonish than I like, but those are minor issues. Overall its a simple concept and a cimple game with a short rulebook that is easy to understand. Good fun can be had playing this game.

title: Solid strategy game
text:
This game is built around the premise that the players have discovered that a new railroad is going to be passing through the town. Each player is a nearby rancher who decides that they want to "own" the town and be able to take advantage of the huge influx of goods and gold that the railroad might bring.

IN the game you do this by taking control over locatoins in town. At first the town is rather small with only a few buildings, but each turn will add additional buildings. Control of a building gives a player special powers that can be used as long as they keep one of their gunhands in the building to protect it.

The play itself is rather simple. Each turn has set steps and the scoring and winning conditions are easy to remmeber.

However, Deadwood is best as a game for 4 people. With 3 the game often becomes a beatdown of one player by the other two.

This is a fun game, but hardly rises up to the level of hte better euro-game and strategy games out there. The idea is nice, but I never fell in love with this game.

title: Quirky and fun, but not a classic
text:
This isn't a hugely complex game. Each player is given a board showing the base zoon and a few coins they can spend for some special actions. The turn starts with a number of empty "trucks" sitting on the table, equal to the number of players. Each player can then.

1) spend coins to expand their zoo or move animals within their zoo
2) draw a tile from the bag. This tile then must be placed on one of the trucks. each "truck" can contain up to three tiles
3) take a truck and put the tiles that were on the truck into their zoo, [after doing this the player is out until all players have claimed trucks]

Strategy comes in because you cannot min animals in an enclosure and the basic zoo only has 3 enclusures, although putting a male and female animal of the same species in an enclosure with extra space will result in a baby animal being bred.

the game continues until there are less than 15 tiles left, at which time points are scored based on how full the zoo's enclosures are. Penalty points are taken away for having animals in the warehouse.

And that's the basic game. Not complex, but easy to describe and teach.

With good players the game goes fast, as the only real strategy is guessing when someone else might claim a "truck" you are trying to build up with the right animals for your zoo. You learn to pay attention to who is collecting which animals.

Sadly, I can't call this a classic game. It's plays a bit too much like a solitare game as the direct interactions are limited. It's not a bad party game as the simple rules will allow teenagers to play, but it can be slow, so I cannot recommend it for the 6-9 year old crowd.

This is definitely more of a gateway game. Good to get people interested in strategy and euro-games, but not necessarily the best game for long term playing. Unless you have a very patient group of friends this game will eventually seem a bit less exciting.

title: Solid Expansion to the original
text:
Expansions to games can always be problematic. It's not unheard of for an expansion to disrupt the balance of power in the game and end up ruining a solid game. However, the makers of Tanto Cuore managed to maintain the level of play with Expanding the House.

The game does not offer a huge expansion to the tactics. The only new type of cards are buildings, which can be purchased and offer victory points much like a maid without going into your deck. In a game where ability to control the cards appearing in your hand, these cards offer a whole new tactic.

The game also comes complete, with everything you need to play. This can be played stand alone, or you can combine this with the original to allow 5 people to play. I've tried both ways, and the game can be great fun.

The only warning I have is that the artwork continues to be rather risque, and is definitely not for young children. Still for lovers of deck building games, this is a solid addition to your game library.

title: Strange concept hides a great game
text:
The idea that each player is in charge of a stone age tribe trying to impress the others by civilizing the fastest is definitely not one might expect. There is no direct conflict in this game. You won't see people throwing dice because two warriors from the tribes faced off in a fight.

But strategy and tactics are vital in this game.

The key is how this game becomes a resource acquisition and dispersal game. You start out with a limited number of people. They can be sent to various spots on the board. Some spots allow you to roll dice and acquire resources. Others spend resources on buildings or civilization improvements (victory points.). You can even send workers to permanently increase food production, make tools or make another worker.

However, there are limitations. The "love shack", food production and tool production spots can only host one tribe each turn. The resource spots allow 7 total tribesmen. If your opponents swarm into the forest first you might end up having to send your people to collect brick, which usually means less resources that turn as wood is easier to gather.

Strategy plays out as you decide where to send your people. You have to make the best use of your opportunities, but also make sure to disrupt your opponents when possible.

It's easy to learn, but will not become boring too quickly as your opponents try tew strategies to defeat you.

title: Made is great attention to detail
text: Models like this are hugely popular in Japan.  Sadly they are very hard to find in the US.  This one came exactly as promised.  Looking at it one can see the incredible attention to detail the Japanese insist on.  For lovers of this kind of model, this is a great addition to any collection.

title: Well made card protectors
text:
I've used card sleeves for years to protect cards from various CCGs. Dragon Shield covers are a bit more expensive than some that you can find, but they are thick and durable, definitely helping add life to your cards.

These were doubly nice as they are clear on both sides. Many cards have colored backing, which can be useful in making all cards look the same when you are mixing decks, but is not necessary when all the cards have the same back.

If you are purchasing a lot of CCG or LCG games, these are definitely something you'll want to purchase as well, to help protect your investment.

title: A small addition to Smallworld
text:
3 new races and 3 new traits is all this addition adds to the game. Overall its not a massive addition or change ot the game. The version I received could have fit into an envelope. Rather than a box you have a sleeve holding the 3 sets of population counters and the race and trait flags. Overall it wasn't much bigger than a CD Jewel Case.

But, even a small addition can expand the options players have and this addition clearly does that with the new races and traits have a huge impact on strategies. In a game where a small mistake can cause you to miss out on multiple victory points and lose the game, this definitely adds to the challenge.

Good for the price, but that's about all.

title: More crazy mayhem
text:
New items, new monsters, more bad puns and silly artwork. If you like the mayhem from the original, or any of the variant, than this is something you'll eventually want. It adds in another race and class for Munchkin.

What's really nice about this expansion is that while it does add to the original, the rules require no major changes and the overall flow remains relatively stable. This expansion just adds possibilities and therefore more fun.

Just as long as you are in the mood to participate in a wild free-for-all.

title: Deck Building idea expanded to a new genre
text:
I've played a lot of different card games. My first intro to deck-building was Dominion and I immediately liked the concept even while I noticed that there were just a few strategies that would be played. So far I've played mroe than 10 games and they all follow about the same victory path even if the 10 card piles change. There are just only so many ways to win.

Tanto Cuore is very similar to Dominion in that you start with 7 love cards (copper in Dominion) and 3 maid chief cards (Estates in Dominion) From this small start you are expected to eventually build a winning deck, by using the love cards to employ maids from the 10 selectable piles. The maids the become cards that can give you additional draws, love for hiring other maids or even allow you to play more than one maid per turn. Simple in concept and easy to learn.

Where Tanto goes beyond Dominion is that some of the maids who have actions also give victory points, and then to add more strategy you can increase the number of points by sending some maids to your private chambers. This removes them from your deck, but gives bonus VP when the game ends. Dominion does not have this element. Some of the maid combinations that can be "chambermaided" are worth more points than the regular VP maids and are much less expensive to purchase into your deck. It adds an additional strategy and more possibilities.

Add in the "private maids" who act like a free action card that activates once a turn, and you have a game with a bit more depth than Dominion. My only complaint would be that this first set only has 16 different general maids, where the base set for dominion has 25 buildings. Tanto Cuore does not have quite as much flexibility as Dominion due to that.

The other nice element is the packaging and cards. Tanto Cuore comes in a nicely decorated card box. Its sized to hold the cards comfortably even if they are sleeved and includes thick cardboard dividers each divicer has a picture of one of the cards in the set, making the initial sorting much easier. The cards are on thick plastic stock rather than the flimsy feeling paper of Dominion.

As long as you don't dislike anime or the idea of hiring maids, this is a good deck building game, the makers put some effort into making the game challenging and fun, and it shows.

title: Bring out the beer and pretzels
text:
Years ago while talking about games one person commented that a certain game was a perfect "beer and pretzels" game. The game in question was simple to play, had lots of off-color humor and while it clearly did not take itself all that seriously, was seriously fun. His comment started a converation about what other games might fit that category.

Munchkin could be the sibling to those old games. Even in this first set, the puns are everywhere and the game is more about having fun and socailizing than winning. Sure it almost requires that you backstab each other freely, but its also the kind of fast paced and humorous game that keeps the players from becoming too serious about what's happening. The idea is to have fun, winning is just a bonus.

The humor can be crude and a bit adult, but other than that Munchkin has proved to be a great game.

title: Appears to be Worth $400
text:
I'm writing the review to alert buyers to the hefty $479.99 and $22.91 shipping that Planet Fun Toys is asking through Amazon. There are considerably higher quotes on line, such as Rakuten's $850.99.

My grandnephew (age 7) is salivating over this toy, so I did some research. It's available as a back order item through the Lego Shop for $399 (shipping included). To save $80 to $500, it's worth waiting until Lego has it available to ship again. I'm old enough to remember when Tickle Me Elmo sold for $2,000 while it was in short supply, and the prices dropped to normal after the manufacturer caught up with the demand.

Over the past two or three years, my grandnephew has enjoyed working with numerous Lego toys, and I've concluded that for the 3,803 pieces inside this 10188 model box, which includes several other little toys that need assembling, $400 is probably a fair price for many hours of fun.

One other comment: the Amazon box display suggests that this toy is for Age 12+ while the Lego shop display says 14+. One teenager didn't find it challenging enough, but lots of fun. A man in his thirties said that it took him twelve to fourteen hours to assemble. Keeping a kid engaged for that amount of time must be priceless, so yes it could be worth $400 to the parents' peace of mind. I already placed the pre-order, but we're offering it to teach the child a lesson - he's been instructed to save for the toy. So far, he has twenty bucks; it's a start.

UPDATE: Lego delivered the Death Star on July 22 and 23 2014 for my grandnephew and for a ten year old girl who also enjoys assembling toys. So, it appears that the Lego warehouses are stocking for the holiday season. Perhaps because I placed more than one order, they discounted $30 off each, mailing was free, Lego purchases earn VIP points that can be used toward other Lego orders, and they sent discount tickets for Lego Land. The downside for the kids: the grandparents are holding the toys until their birthday or Christmas. I was informed that each box is huge and weighs 26 lbs.

Then you can use the more PG cards when you need to and pull out the full deck when it is safe. That way you can play the game more often, or with teens or elderly relatives present. There are several blank cards in the deck. Don't use them right away. Keep a list of answers you WISHED you had while playing. That will make it obvious soon enough what to put on the blank cards.

title: Great little machine
text:
I bought several different types of bubble machines for an event.
Having tried out a half dozen, this is the one I am keeping.

Pros - tiny, lightweight, can do battery or wall power, affordable.
Bubbles float high, are nicely spaced, and are in many different sizes.
There was no dribble or splatter under the machine.

Cons - the motor is loud, the housing is not all black (if you want it hidden),
It takes 3 seconds from hitting on to getting noticeable bubbles (only matters if your bubbles have to happen at a specific moment.
The fluid reservoir is small, so you will need to refill more frequently. But the unit is compact, so no surprise.

In short, worth every penny, but may be a little too loud for an intimate setting.

title: Cool project, but too many flaws. Not worth price.
text: This looked so cool! It was a great project to work on with my 13 year old. We had a good time working as a team and reading the directions. Until it was completed. The shaft that holds the 3 gears is too wobbly and unsteady to work properly. The elevator lift does not lift high enough to get the ball onto the ramps, not low enough to grab another ball. And the gear that carries the ball over and onto the higher ramp only works 1 in ever 5 times. And the holes to allow the ball to pass through were too small to work, so we had to file the piece for quite a while. (I assume that was a flaw in the wood??) We watched videos online and retraced our steps, to no avail. We googled ideas to problem solve and found nothing helpful. We had all of the pieces and the learning experience was good. But, I have a frustrated teen now and a project that certainly wasn't worth the $40. A disappointment and would not recommend, unfortunately.

title: On Earth, no one can hear them scream
text:
What it is:

1. A multipurpose alien spaceship, which allows kids to create different types of aliens using the half-molds provided, and save them in the transparent pods.
2. Tubs of "meteor mud" to make the desired alien imprint.
3. Tubes of "lunar lava" gel to make the aliens.
4. Implements, with which you can probe, flatten and otherwise annihilate the alien population.
5. A light-up display with a volcano which can be used to squish aliens. (Batteries included)

Pros:

1. Very easy to use and set up, and even smaller kids can use it with supervision.
2. The "meteor mud" (A modeling clay/play-doh combination) is reusable.
3. Can make up to 90 different aliens
4. Fun to dissect, squish and mutilate, especially when their innards are still gooey and runny.
5. Unlike Ripley's Aliens, these are created non-invasively, painlessly and relatively mess-free.

Cons:

1. The aliens are itsy bitsy and teenie weenie (yellow polka dot bikinis optional)
2. There's only one creation chamber, and each alien takes five minutes to set, so there's a lot of waiting time, which seems longer when several kids are playing "mad scientist".
3. Some aliens are harmed in the extraction process from the "meteor mud"
4. The novelty wears off pretty quickly, but should buy you a few hours of peace and quiet while your progeny create and destroy defenseless alien life forms.

Recommended for children who like to squish things, future astronauts, budding mad scientists, or anybody past the age of five.

Amanda Richards, April 19, 2009

title: Added Snap!
text:
This kit is for kids who already have [[ASIN:B00008BFZH Snap Circuits Jr. SC-100]], and have completed all 101 experiments from the enclosed booklet.

What you get:

More snap wire connections, including one with 7 snaps. (Each "snap" clicks into place on the board to connect the circuits)

Another battery holder

An antenna coil

A green LED

A 6V lamp socket and bulb

A microphone

A power amplifier integrated circuit

Capacitors

Resistors

A high frequency integrated circuit

Transistors

A booklet with instructions for projects 102-305

Note: You don't get another board. They're assuming you have the first kit with the board and components.

Projects in this kit include doorbells, buzzers, fans, alarms and all manner of sound effects.

Recommended if you already have the first set and your kids are aching for more projects. Educational, fun and a snap to use.

Amanda Richards, January 24, 2009
