title: Good practice for Caribbean traffic
text:
[[VIDEOID:76c047bc1b993585ece6eeb0c23911bb]] If you're looking for a challenging yet low-tech family game, look no further.

Believe it or not, this one doesn't plug in anywhere, needs no batteries, has no tangles of wire to connect, makes no noise, and best of all, doesn't have hundreds of expensive add-ons, memory cards and other related stuff that you have to buy.

It takes up almost no space, comes with its own little carrier bag, and provides hours of educational fun for all ages.

You can take this on a plane
You can take this on a train
You can take this here or there
You can take this ANYWHERE

What you get:

1. A small plastic game board with a handy storage drawer and a slot for the game card in play
2. A bunch of colored plastic cars and trucks
3. A deck of game cards with clearly illustrated traffic jam situations for different skill levels
4. A drawstring cloth carrier bag

What you do:

1. Start with the Beginner cards and work your way up to the Advanced level
2. Set up the cars on the board as indicated on the card
3. Try to get the little red car to the only exit by driving forward and reversing the vehicles on the board until the way is clear
4. Try not to tear your hair out or use bad language at the vehicles blocking you
5. Try not to peek at the answers on the back of the card

When you're through with this one, there are four additional game sets at ridiculously affordable prices. Each one gives you one more vehicle and another set of game cards.

Believe me, when you graduate from this traffic school you'll be able to drive in the Caribbean without any problems.

Amanda Richards, December 28, 2008

title: Domo arigato Santa Claus
text:
[[VIDEOID:29963661]]So, Santa came through this year. After 6 months of lists, hints, and wheedling, this voice changer helmet found its way under the Christmas tree, and we're even considering letting the kid play with it.

It is of sturdy plastic construction, with impressively detailed features, and best of all, it can fit an adult sized head, thanks to an adjustable strap at the back.

It works with 3 AA batteries (included), and using buttons at the side, you can make it say four battle phrases or make the sound of Prime transforming. Of course it also changes your own voice to sound robotic, even though you'll have to at least TRY to sound like Optimus Prime to make it sound genuine. Way cool even if you don't manage to send shivers down Decepticon spines.

The only minor problem is that is also changes the voices of people close to you, so once they're speaking, you'll also hear their voices transform.

Anyway, gotta run - Decepticons to defeat and all that.
Transform, and roll out!!

Amanda Richards, December 25, 2008

title: Wash-out
text:
[[VIDEOID:19354301]]This gizmo is fun for about 6 minutes and 20 seconds, not including set-up time. It's okay to a point once you're using the coloring pages or stencils supplied, but doesn't encourage self-expression or creativity.

Pros:
1. No mess, other than the occasional splatter of white stuff, which is easy to clean up.
2. Sprayer makes a professional sounding noise
3. Includes three stencils, with interesting patterns
4. Easy to set up
5. Includes everything you need except batteries

Cons:
1. It uses FOUR "C" batteries (not included)
2. The colors only work on Crayola special paper.
3. The colors are pale, washed out looking tints of the colors they claim to be
4. The colors don't show up immediately, and as a result, kids tend to spray the same area over and over again, causing a wet spot
5. The coloring pages are specially created so that the paint only sticks to specific areas, thereby guaranteeing a good finish. Similarly, the stencils only let through the paint in the right places. Kids can draw their own images using the markers and crayon, but it's impossible to keep the spray within the lines, resulting in major frustration for kids who want to express themselves beyond the coloring pages and stencils.

Recommended only for short term entertainment, when you don't feel like cleaning up afterwards. Not for creative kids.

Amanda Richards, March 20, 2008

title: This is a snap!!
text:
[[VIDEOID:17092331]]This is the ideal kit to get your child on the road to understanding electricity. Everything just snaps together like building blocks, and there's no need for screwdrivers, soldering irons, electrical tape or testers.

The instruction manual is easy to read, and includes diagrams for 101 projects. With a little help for the first few, a child can easily work their way through the book with minimal adult supervision.

The video shows a few of the projects - a switch circuit with light bulb, running a DC motor and fan, a Space War alarm combo, and a flying saucer. There's also a clip of a lamp and fan in series, showing that the fan takes a while to turn at full speed because of inertia.

There are also games, sirens, projects activated by clapping or light, and projects that introduce digital circuits. There are three kits that are more advanced, but you can also get upgrade kits to take each to the next level.

If you're looking for an educational toy that your child will really enjoy, I recommend you put this one on your list.

Amanda Richards, December 30, 2007

title: I spy with my EyeClops eye
text:
Things you should know about the EyeClops

1. Even though set-up is relatively easy, kids may need some help in putting it together, connecting it to the TV and bringing the bionic eye into focus.
a. The lens attachment has to be placed over the bionic eye, and twisted until the red groove is aligned with the arrows.
b. This toy needs five AA batteries for the "brain case"
c. It needs to be connected to the TV video input
d. It has to be focused using the focusing disc (included) before use

2. It's not for smaller children who may shine the LED light in their eyes

3. It comes with a viewing tube (for looking at bugs and other small objects); a viewing dish (for stuff that needs a little more room to spread out for examination); and a base for hands free viewing. These items are made of transparent plastic, and if you're not careful you may throw them away with the packaging.

4. It comes with an easy to understand, illustrated instruction booklet, that's actually written in proper English, and includes a treasure hunt section.

Good things about the EyeClops

1. Kids will be fascinated by the 200X magnification, and are likely to spend lots of time looking for objects to view
2. This is a good learning tool for showing kids what everyday objects look like up close. Hair, skin, salt, coins and banknotes, magazines, cloth and carpets are good examples, as are ants, fruit flies, shells and leaves. You can actually see fibers in cloth, and hair and follicles in skin.
3. Great gross out fun when disgusting objects appear on your TV screen

Bad things about the EyeClops

1. The object for examination needs to be very close to the bionic eye, touching the lens attachment
2. You can only view objects in the proximity of the TV, up to the length of the cord.
3. Sometimes the image appears fuzzy and adjustments have to be made to get it into focus
4. Some colors view better than others
5. Once the batteries start running down you get lines through the image and discoloration
6. If you're using this with your kids - DON'T LET THEM SEE A CLOSE-UP OF YOUR SKIN. This device clearly illustrates the aging process, and the difference between young skin and ummm older skin is very apparent. Unless you want them laughing at you for years to come, don't show your epidermis without a fight.

A cool educational toy for kids with a little parental guidance required.

Amanda Richards, December 24, 2007

title: Realistically cool!
text:
Mater may be one of the easiest to find die cast characters from the movie "Cars", but he's certainly the one with the most rustic (and rusty) charm.

He comes with faded paint, rusty rims, missing hood, rear view mirrors and tow hook (the last two are made of plastic), and my son was overjoyed to find out that this model actually squeaks when it moves.

All the characters in the die cast series that I have seen so far are well made, very strong, and sized perfectly for take-along entertainment, but the one who truly deserves a 5 star review for brilliant attention to detail is good ole Mater.

Whether you're a child, a parent or a collector you're really gonna get a kick out of Mater.

Amanda Richards, January 1, 2007

title: One and a half years and still going strong
text:
Santa brought this tent and tunnel for my son in 2003, and it was an immediate hit. He is now 3 years old, and still enjoys playing with it.
Last week, he took it to a fun day at school, where three classes of active kids gave it a try out. It stood up admirably, and went back into its storage bag proud and intact. It took a huge amount of abuse and shrugged it off. I was deeply impressed, because I never expected it to last this long. Several teachers and parents asked me where I got it from, so I guess they were also impressed.
It stores easily in the handy bag, and the tunnel when strapped up takes up little space. It's light, portable, affordable and fun.
One of the best toys I have ever purchased on Santa's behalf.

title: Real cute on Little Harry Potters
text:
I bought this costume for my son for his second birthday party, which had a Harry Potter theme. (See my "How To" guide for organising an unforgettable Harry Potter party in the "So you'd like to ..." section)
The one I got came with a fancy clasp to hold the front of the cape together. It was a little big, so I had to hem it and roll up the sleeves. Even after hard wear and much abuse at the party it washed well, and looks like new. He will probably still have this costume when Books 6 and 7 come out.
The wand is realistic, but with young children you have to watch out for them hitting other children with it, as it's pretty solid.
The glasses are also very authentic looking, and fits all faces (mine included). Again you have to be careful with younger children as it tends to slide off little noses, and the glass might break. I haven't had any problems with it mind you, but it could happen. The lenses get dirty quickly also.
The transfers are a very nice touch, and they go on easily with a little water. Even squirmy kids can be decorated without too much fuss. They last a couple of days if you don't scrub them too hard in the bath. I removed my son's own, because it was so realistic that people kept coming up to me asking if he had fallen and hurt his forehead. (Muggles no doubt!)
A great buy for your little Harry Potter

title: The grandson loves it
text: At 2 years old I thought he might not be able to get up on the horse, but it took all of 5 minutes for that to be an after thought. He loves the sounds and spends lots of energy trying to make it rock as much as possible for long periods of time. This wears him down which his parents appreciate, kids have so much excess energy. It took approximately 45 minutes to assembly and was easy from start to finish. I'm sure he will get years of joy out of the horse just as our son did when he was young. It takes 3 triple A batteries and has 3 settings for the sound of off, low and loud. He enjoys the loud trotting and whinnie sounds, but the low setting is good when you need a bit more silence. The rocking motion is virtually silent, only the interactive sounds can be heard.

text: Got these for easy doodling on a long flight. Nice firm cards, effect looks good. You get a lot of them. Can use as notes on reverse side or on coated side, why not.

title: Not safe for family holidays
text: This puzzle is definitely not suitable for children or a family activity. It's a little lewd and that's fine for grownups who knows what they are getting into. I intended to do this puzzle with pre-teen nieces.... NOPE

title: Great realistic horse images, fun party favors
text: Our City sponsored a community wide Christmas event last week and my Municipal District contributed party favors, Santa and food for everyone. One of the party favors we used were these horse stickers/tattoos for the kids. I was impressed as a horse person with the number of realistic horses in this set. It's not all cartoonish or over exaggerated images - the realistic ones were all the older kids wanted actually. These come off easily and cleanly as well.

title: Great office toy set for visiting kids
text: One of my board members brings her little girl to most meetings and we've set up a little play area for her. When I brought out these dinosaur toys and the interactive book the other day, she lit up like Christmas. Her mom and I were actually able to have a full, uninterrupted conversation for almost an hour because the kid was enthralled. The dinosaurs are pretty cool with realistic colors and detailing. The book is awesome and the sound effects are lots of fun.

title: Fun puzzle, colorful
text:
My husband does a group puzzle every week with the ladies at the RV park. Everyone contributes one new puzzle every month in the winter. They've accumulated a cabinet full. They rotate the puzzles in the summer and revisit old ones.

This camper image was smaller than the ones they usually work with at just 500 pieces. But all 5 extolled the cuteness of it and the detailed image made the puzzle more challenging despite the fewer pieces. The finished product is definitely attractive.

title: Not a fan of the same shape pieces
text: We do a community puzzle thing with a group of retired ladies at an RV park. My husband has coffee with them every morning and they work on the puzzles. This one was exciting at first glance because it's a lovely image with lots of colors. Unfortunately, this is one of those puzzles with the same shape pieces. It's not as fun as the traditional JIGSAW pieces of various shapes and angles. It turns out that no one in the group likes this type actually. The finished puzzle looks nice, but it was a labor of disappointment rather than fun.

title: Normal type of jigsaw puzzle, harder than most
text: This is a normal style of puzzle - irregular shaped pieces and no hints on the back of the pieces. I prefer this type - it makes you really focus and think and you appreciate it more when you've finished it. We have it set up in the laundry room of the RV park and there are several ladies who share the puzzles every week. My husband and i finished this puzzle ourselves at home before passing it on and it was hard. The Puzzle Ladies are having a ball though and thoroughly challenged.

title: Same shape pieces
text: I'm not thrilled with this new type of puzzle. All the pieces are the same shape with a hint on the back. It's just not as fun and begins to feel tedious.

title: Pretty finished product
text: Our puzzle group has enjoyed this one. We each work on a shared puzzle every day. This one was fun and not finished too easily. The pieces were cut properly and fit together correctly. The finished puzzle is quite pretty.

title: Easy, but not too easy for a casual puzzle fan
text: I wanted a fun, reasonably simple puzzle that was unusual. We have a group of ladies that share a big puzzle weekly and everyone works on it at different times. A way to do something together without being in an enclosed space during pandemic stuff. This one has been a big hit despite only taking a single day to finish between the four of us. It's unusual and interesting and the finished puzzle was quite cute. The fox was a nice break between the giant jigsaw puzzles we normally do.

title: Cups get soggy, plates are fine
text: We use paper plates in the RV often for obvious reasons. These are decent for quick breakfast pancakes or waffles. They don't get soggy even with syrup. Unfortunately, the little cups get soggy at the seam line very fast - definitely not for tea or coffee.

title: Comfortable, easy to inflate
text:
Outstanding! I've used this for several hours at Balmoreah State Park in West Texas and it's been awesome. It was a cinch to inflate and it's stayed inflated for 48 hours and lots of time in the water.

It's easy to get in and out of. Floating sitting up, on your stomach or on your back is smooth and level. No low sinky spots. It's small enough to carry around unlike those big tubes or flat floats. I'm super pleased.

title: Really trashy questions- not for every group
text: Ok, I fully appreciate creative cursing and a solid dirty joke. Our circle of closest friends enjoys a risque board game now and then and we're all pretty easy going and very hard to offend. So I figured this NSFW card game would be fun. It's a little too far for even us. Some of the questions are so tacky I would never ask them or even want to hear the answer from anyone else. Definitely read through these before playing in a group just to be sure that your group is suitable.

title: Horse crazy niece loves this
text: My niece has always been enchanted by our show horses. Even as a baby, she would giggle and grab the ribbons braided into the horses' manes at shows. I knew she would love this and I was right. I was able to share it with her on their last visit before the Covid stay at home orders. She said that she really likes the magnet effect and it's easy to play with all the parts. I'm glad I let her take it home now that she's stuck in the house.

title: Cute and realistic
text:
My husband and I love dogs more than anything else on the planet. For years we've been collecting dog themed Christmas tree ornaments. When I saw this Golden Retriever family, I knew it would be a great tree addition.

The dogs are much more realistic than expected and the whole set is adorable. They have facial expressions and just look like happy Goldens should. I hot glued ribbon to each piece and they are ready to be ornaments.

title: Very nicely done, great as converted to Christmas tree ornaments
text: My husband and I love dogs more than anything else on the planet. For years we've been collecting dog themed Christmas tree ornaments. When I saw this Dalmatian set, I knew it would be a great tree addition. The dogs are much more realistic than expected and the whole set is adorable. I hot glued ribbon to each piece and they are ready to be ornaments.

title: Decent quality set for our weekend cabin
text:
I grew up playing Chinese Checkers and gin rummy with both my Grandfathers. The memories of sitting on the porch in the fall evenings with sweet tea and Chinese Checkers have stayed with me my entire life. I definitely want to recreate that for my nieces when we are all out at the ranch.

This set is pretty sturdy for adults and older, coordinated kids - I would never expect a six or seven year old to be able to refrain from knocking everything over. I'm happy to have this set out in the weekend cabin -you don't need WiFi or internet to have fun with people you love.

title: Fun with grown ups game night
text: We do a game night/potluck dinner once a month with two other couples and I am responsible for the games. This is a new one for our group, but it was well received. There are a lot of cards and questions on both sides, so we can play another couple of times without repeating any questions. Lots of interesting facts and random info here that generate conversation.  Our group has a history teacher in it and we had great fun at his expense when he missed a couple of the answers. The game play is simple and can be modified for your group if you choose. I'll keep this in our game rotation.

title: Huggable, huge and soft
text: Originally, my intention was to have this giant stuffed dog for my nieces to sleep with when they visit us. However, the 1 year old puppy has taken the stuffed dog as her own cuddly toy. She's dragged it into her crate and if I remove it, she sneaks it back. It's pretty darn cute and since Beth isn't chewing it up, I am letting her keep it. The toy is very soft and huggable and seems well made.

title: Cute, soft and cuddly
text: I got this giant duck for our senior dogs to snuggle with and they love it. The 15 year old Beagle mix has slept with it for five nights now and the 15 year old Rhodesian Ridgeback likes to attack it. Neither dog is chewing it up, just enjoying it. The duck is very soft and cuddle friendly and it's pretty darn cute.

title: Great new Barbie for when my niece visits
text: I have a 6 year old niece who is just like her Mother - obsessed with every iteration of Barbie and her universe. I saw this one with the puppies and knew it was perfect for her when she visits us. The Barbie doll is your typical, blonde Barbie and looks like all the others to me. She comes with several very cute dogs and a couple of accessories for them. My niece was absolutely thrilled when they were here for the holidays and promptly named every dog and had me print little labels for them. That's a win on the Aunt Score Card

title: Very soft and cheerful.
text: There's a lot to like here with this hippopotamus. He's soft and cuddly with lots of colors and places to grab with tiny hands. The included carbiner connects to a stroller or frib which is nice. You can also use it as a little puppet - there's a hole on the back to insert a hand.

title: Funny and very cute. Love the flapping wings
text: I wanted this as a toy for my niece when she visits and it's so charming, I almost hate to let a kid play with it. The sound is very clear and easy to understand. Those fun flapping wings are hysterical. This penguin has to be the cutest thing I've found for my niece yet.

title: Our cat jumped on this soft toy and won't give it back
text: I got this rainbow kitten to use as a decorative prop for our monthly game night - this month Exploding Kittens is in rotation as the October game. However, the Siamese cat stumbled upon this plush sitting on the dining room table and claimed it. He's been batting it around and pouncing on it all day. It's a soft, well made toy and more charming than expected.... also, apparently, this is a great cat toy.

title: Adult fun and humor that creates its own silly jokes
text:
We do a game night once a month with two other couples and it's my job to provide the game each month. Everyone else handles the food. I've had a couple of serious flops this year and we had to resort to cards, so I was cautiously optimistic with Brown Chicken.

Turns out that this is fun, funny and tasteless n the exact right way for our group. This is definitely an adults only game. None of us has any artistic skills so our clay models were pretty sketchy at best. That just made it funnier and we drifted off the game into our own spontaneous raunchy jokes. We'll put this game into the rotation and play it again.

title: Fun, but not as much as hoped for. Better suited for a family than group of adults
text: We do a game night every month with a group of friends and I try to bring a new game as often as possible. This one is easy to play with a group of four to six people and can definitely Garner some very funny moments. However, there are some harder voices to try to do - like Dog - everyone ended up doing Scooby Doo. We all played one full game, but that was about all we could stand. I think this game is better suited to playing with your kids than just a group of adults.

title: Seriously funny with a cat. Flies and maneuvers really well. Lots of fun
text:
I read the Harry Potter books when they first came out and watched the movies, but honestly, have not given the Potter world another thought in years. Until I saw this actually flying Snitch. I had to have it - how often does something fictional truly come to life?

It has to be charged for at least thirty minutes before you can fly it and the charge only gives you about 5 or 6 actual minutes of real flying time. Normally, that would be irritating, but I've had so much fun with the Snitch that I'm willing to overlook the short play time. The ball glows red as it's charging and stops when it's finished.

You have to hold the Snitch perfectly vertical, press the on button on the bottom and the start button on the little remote. However, that's all the remote does as far as I can tell. The Snitch is significantly louder than expected and it's fast. If you put your hand under it as it flies by, it will move up and away. I've only used it inside and it will crash into walls or potted plants, but so far none of the crashes have damaged it. The cat is seriously infatuated with the Snitch both flying and sitting still, turned off. He's all about catching and killing the Snitch - I laughed so hard yesterday that I was crying watching the cat chase this across the house. I would totally buy a replacement if we kill this one.

title: Joystick is slow and herky-jerky making game play difficult
text:
Let me preface this review by saying that I loved Mrs Pac-Man back in the day and I've never really grown out of that. So I was tickled to see this little retro video game box with the pink bow girl chasing ghosts. There's a little joystick and the start button makes a little sound like a quarter dropping at the beginning of the game.

However, the childlike joy sort of deflates within moments after you start playing. The maze is correct and the sounds are right, but the graphics are faint and hard to see in certain light. Additionally, the joystick is jerky and slow to respond which means Ms Pac-Man gets stuck in corners or simply doesn't turn. By the time you get the joystick jiggled just right, the ghosts are already on you. I like the retro feel, but the funtionality is pretty rough.

title: Repurposed for motor skills therapy with older child
text:
I actually got this to use as a sort of physical therapy tool with a friend's little girl who recently suffered a severe brain injury requiring surgery. She's having to relearn a number of fine motor skills and some speech and movement control. At 12, she's both horse crazy and puppy crazy, so I thought working on rehabilitating this stuffed dog together when I visit her at the hospital might be a fun/useful thing.

It's actually been a better project than I had hoped. She and I have pulled the "flea" stickers off, unbandaged the paw, brushed the pup and she named him Hope. Tomorrow we'll muss him up and do it again - well, not the fleas because those don't go back on. However, I think I can create some homemade nonsense to stick on the dog that we can clean off. The actual of checking the doll, cleaning it, brushing it, hugging it etc brought a little fun to the work of physical and occupational therapy.

I probably wouldn't suggest this for a younger child just because there seems to be limited actual play opportunity here since the accessories are pretty much one time use.

title: Apparently, this is the ideal cat bed according to our Siamese
text: This is really soft and thick and just feels like something you want to snuggle up with. It's exactly the right size, the right shape and the perfect thickness for a cat bed. Our Siamese immediately claimed this and has refused to relinquish it.

title: Easy to play with a group of Gen Xers over pizza and beer
text:
We do game night once a month or so with a group of friends over dinner and we're always happy to have a new game to try. This is an easy one to play. It's even more fun to modify by tossing the rules completely and just taking turns answering the questions and letting the conversation flow.

We're a group of 6 adults ranging in age from our mid 40s to late 50s so the 80s and 90s were definitely our generation's young adult years. Kids in their 20 something's probably aren't going to get the nostalgia kick out of this game that we do - they won't remember why We Are The World meant something or what Max Headroom was or why New Coke was so awful. This isn't a game we'll play often, but once a year or so for a jig down memory lane, this one is a good choice.

title: Soft and huggable
text: This has to be the cutest monster ever. He's amazingly soft and touchable - you just want to snuggle with him. My niece visits often and I keep a selection of toys and stuffed animals here just for her. She grabbed this with that sort of delight that only a five year old has. Monster is a hit here.

title: Overly complicated, less funny than other similar games.
text: We have a group of three couples for game night once a month and we love trying a new game. However, this one just didn't go over well with our group - everyone is well over 40, so that might have been part of it. It seems unnecessarily complicated and wasn't even close to as funny as some other games in this genre. Honestly, we only got through about 30 minutes here before calling it a loss and going back to an old stand by game. (Cards Against Humanity) It's not awful, it just didn't resonate with our group of six grown-ups.

title: The puppy stole this and loves it. It's stiffer than most stuffed toys
text:
I thought I would keep this in guest room with other toys for my niece when she's here. It's the right size for snuggling and quite cute. However, this isn't a soft, cuddly stuffed toy. It's surprisingly stiff and solid feeling.

None of that matters anymore though. Our 7 month old Greater Swiss Mountain Dog puppy has claimed this. She snuck into the guest room and stole it. She's been carrying it around for days - not chewing it up, just taking it everywhere she goes. It's pretty darn cute actually.

title: Light weight, flimsy plastic parts. Tips over and spills very easily
text:
My husband and I both loved Battleship as kids, so we were happy to have a set today. We do a monthly game night with friends and we play games or cards together often. Battleship is a good choice for a cold, quiet night by a fire for two people. Unfortunately, we were both disappointed by this new version.

It is played the same as always and includes one airplane for each player in addition to the original five ships. The problem is the boxes each player uses are made of very thin, cheap plastic. Tipping it over and splattering the pegs everywhere is too easy. There's a removable plastic tray for the opponent's ship grid - this thing pops out unexpectedly and tosses pegs everywhere. The entire set up is very flimsy. We both remember the original game being heavier and thicker, more sturdy in general. I'm not comfortable letting my niece use this with me simply because if it spills or the top piece pops out she'll end up frustrated.

title: Multiple typos, overly complicated play and too many different activities
text:
For several years, we have done a game night with two other couples at least once a month - we play cards, dominos, board games, murder mystery dinners, laser tag, basketball on horses and we've even done the Escape Room thing. Playing this game tonight was a natural way to test it out. The Horrible Truth is that this one will not ever be in our rotation again.

The box is very clearly marked "Explicit Content", so the inclusion of profanity, sexual innuendo, and bodily function jokes wasn't a surprise. We're a pretty open minded and easy going group and it takes more than a few tacky questions or obscene stick figures to bother any of us. There are a lot of those things in the game, BTW.

Our issues were related to the structure of the game and it's execution. The instructions and actual game play are overly complicated for no obvious reason. The voting and answer tiles are too small for big fingers to grip easily and it really needs a little holder for them - like for Scrabble tiles. The game itself is trying too hard to be too many things - a bit of Truth or Dare mixed with Explicit Pictionary and a little Cards Against Humanity. We found the Draw It cards elicited the most laughs and whole group engagement. My final complaint is the misspelled words on several cards! Seriously? This is just bad editing and bad quality control and I certainly wouldn't pay money for a game with typos.

title: Very stable, perfect for floating gently with a book in the pool. Enormous
text:
Wow, this is really enormous, but in a fun way. It has 5 inflation valves so you definitely need a pump to inflate it - there's no blowing it up manually. The float is designed to hold three people comfortably and it is designed well. The whole thing is properly balanced so a single user can be comfortable and not worry about tipping over.

I'm loving this island float in our pool as a place to lounge with a book. It doesn't bounce, tip over or wobble - even if you paddle it around, it moves, but doesn't feel unsteady. Flipping it upside down gives a flat surface to lie on your stomach comfortably if you are so inclined. Technically, this behemoth is too big for our small pool, but I love it anyway. It's big enough for my other big tube float to fit in it with room left over. I could see this being used as a swim out floating island in a lake etc.

UPDATE 1 week later *****

This float is losing air much more quickly than the blue one in the photos. I've had to add air to the center seat area three times in a week. There's no discernible leak and it's in the water all the time. The head rests are holding air fine. The comparison is my Intex river tube float - I add air to it once every two weeks at the most.

title: Soft, cuddly and irresistible to a 6 year old girl
text:
So I thought that this unicorn would be a cute little addition to our horse specific Christmas decorations at the barn. It might well have been if only my niece hadn't found it first.

She's 6 and has that magical little girl radar that allows her to instantly know there's a stuffed toy somewhere close. She latched onto this within minutes of walking in our door and slept with it, played with it, squeezed the sound player and carried it around nonstop for the three days she was here. This morning, she solemnly handed it back and I promised to keep it in the toy box that is reserved for her visits. I'm actually just going to buy her one as a surprise gift for her own house.

title: Surprisingly sturdy and comfortable. Great for reading and floating n the pool
text:
Perfect for lounging in the pool with a book and a glass of sweet tea. This is big enough to actually be comfortable, but too big for multiple floats in a smaller home pool. If we get back out to the Guadalupe River this summer, it will be ideal for tubing.

I inflated this 8 days ago and have used it almost every day after swimming laps. Today is the first time that it seems a bit under inflated....that's pretty reasonable in my book. The handles are sturdy and the bottom netting allows for water flow without being swamped. I can sit cross legged comfortably or stretch out with my feet in the water and no risk of the float flipping me out. I'm going to buy a second one for my husband to use.

title: Absolutely hysterical when the cat bats it around. Lifelike and well made
text:

I think this is my favorite way to prank our pets - I plan to do Lemur on a Ledge this Christmas and boot that Elf off our shelf.

The construction here is top notch and he's stiff and sturdy enough to stand on his own. Half of the tail from the haunches out is stiff, but the end half is flexible. Our Siamese cat has had a ball swatting the tail and flat out pouncing on this thing and giving it full body rolls whenever it "appears" around a corner unexpectedly. Our dogs are equally enthusiastic about tossing it around.

title: Sturdy hats with adjustable straps
text:
Well, these are shown as party hats for babies.
But that isn't why I got them.

Yes we are among "those" people who celebrate their pets' birthdays. Ha! I wanted to see how they would work for photos. As it turns out, they will work just fine!

The hats themselves are nice and sturdy. But my favorite part is the easily adjustable neck strap which keeps the hat on the head. This was so easy to slide up under our cats' chins. It made it so much easier to keep a hat on their heads for photos. (I imagine you would have the same results with a baby, but don't have one handy to try it out.)

Overall, I was very happy with these little hats. They did exactly what I had hoped for, and are a decent quality as well.

title: Thin but cute
text:
These are fairly cute decorations. These are not as sturdy as another more common brand of shoe decorations, but they fit easily into the holes, and did not rub on the foot or toes.

They are very colorful, and look cute on the shoes.

title: Great for extra dice
text: With so many games using dice, it is always good to have a few extra on hand. Sometimes, one will just roll away and disappear! These are priced right and do a great job.

title: Great for Skellington fans
text:
My son loves all things associated with the Nightmare Before Christmas. So, he wanted this game, of course.

We played this at New Year. It was okay. The game ends up being very short, since whoever has Jack can use the special cards. Whoever gets 5 special cards wins. That does not take very long the way the game is set up.
So, more for the novelty than for fun game play.

title: Not soft at all. Hard plastic with rough edges
text:
Well, this is a cute dinosaur-shaped toy, but NOT what I expected.

This is not a soft silicone to touch and squeeze, although it looks like it; this is hard plastic. The back had several VERY sharp little edges where it was probably popped out of a mold. But to ship them out with sharp edges is pretty unacceptible. We took a nail file to ours. Even then, our fidgiter was not very interested in it beyond being a bright green dinosaur.

I don't recommend this one. Careless edges and hard plastic.

title: Very handy, esp for people with arthritis
text:
This shuffler is all plastic. All plastic.
It has a Las Vegas sticker on it to make a nod to gambling. It wasn't really needed and adds nothing. There are no instructions on the box or in the box. When I picked this out, I thought it would be battery operated. It is not. This is all manual. Not bad, but not specified either.

There is a plastic cranks on the bottom of the machine. The crank fits in the back of the shuffler. You just divide your cards in half (no need to be exact), put a stack on each side, and turn the crank. The newly shuffled deck is now in the middle, in the plastic clear tray. You just slide the tray out. You can reshuffle the deck as many times as desired.

This would be very handy for people with arthritis or other hand problems. Some folks just have a really hard time shuffling cards - this would be a big help for them as well.

Overall, for being 100% plastic, it worked very well.

title: Good for fidgeters
text:
This is an interesting item. As the mom of an adhd kid, I wish these things had existed when he was younger.

It seems distracted kids do better with something in their hands to keep fidgeting localized, if you will.

This toy offers several types of fidget release. If your child is throwing things, I do NOT recommend this one - it would be very painful to be hit by this.

I think this also has some potential in a nursing home situation, especially in memory care facilities. Often, dementia or ALZ loved ones will wring their hands or grab at things. There is a chance that this item might help them with the fidgeting aspect, but not totally sure. Texture is often important as well, so it will totally depend on the individual and what they need.

title: Ok. A little TOO big
text:
[[VIDEOID:de5c49dac004f5d81a414e6a714563d8]] These are ok. I have an ADHD son, so thought maybe these would be interesting to try.

In my opinion, the idea behind it is great; something to do for fidgety hands. But they seem way too big! It nearly takes two hands to mess with them.

They also don't technically have a top and bottom, but the "pop" works better from one side than the other. I also felt that the pop worked better while pushing up from the bottom, rather than down from the top.

Overall, great idea. Easy to clean. Will keep fidgeters busy. The downside is that they are a little too big for subtle use or one-handed use.

title: MUCH lighter weight and smaller than original pawns
text:
I bought these because we had a missing pawn in our Sorry game. I shopped based on 1" size, and did not think about other factors.

Wow, are these cheap!! Molded and popped off frames of some kind, these are hollow on the bottom and have little rough, sharp stems on the top.

I am going to try a nail file to take down the sharpness on the top. These are of course, very light weight, so they won't feel like other pieces. They have a much smaller base as well, so will not be as steady to move around the board. Note in my photos...hollow bottoms with smaller base size, which means much less stability on the game board.
Also note the total size difference:
This purchased game piece on the left, an original Sorry game piece on the right.

Overall, I wish I would have realized the horizontal size difference. I would have paid more to get better pieces. But if you have kids who lose game pieces a lot, or are creating your own games, these should work just fine.

title: It works fine. Just know it is 100% plastic
text:
[[VIDEOID:3d2cc7ee545b62e002c964aea89f7949]] My parents used to have a metal card shuffler. They were avid pinochle players and used the plastic-coated Kem cards. The shuffler was a hand-saver.

This shuffler is sadly all plastic. All plastic. It has a Las Vegas sticker on it to make a nod to gambling. It wasn't really needed and adds nothing.

There are no instructions on the box or in the box. When I picked this out, I thought it would be battery operated. It is not. This is all manual. Not bad, but not specified either.

There are two little plastic cranks on the bottom of the machine. You only need one, so I am assuming you get a spare crank. The crank fits in the back of the shuffler. You just divide your cards in half (no need to be exact), put a stack on each side, and turn the crank. The newly shuffled deck is now in the middle, in a plastic clear tray. You just slide the tray out. You can reshuffle the deck as many times as desired.

This would be very handy for people with arthritis or other hand problems. Some folks just have a really hard time shuffling cards - this would be a big help for them as well.

Overall, for being 100% plastic, it worked very well. Please see my video review to see it in use.

title: Just drum shaped noise
text:
[[VIDEOID:82c460f51abcbd27014c15e6ec79034b]] Wow. I don't want to be mean, but I want to leave an honest review too. This set is larger than I thought. I guess the measurements were buried in the description, but when I saw the basic description, I was thinking finger tapping.

This takes up about a foot of room. The drum tops are super thin plastic sheeting. Everything is, of course, some kind of plastic. The drumsticks look like Shrek's cotton swabs, made of molded gray plastic. The cymbal is silver tone and some thin metal that doesn't make much of a sound.

Now, if I wanted to encourage my child to play a musical instrumemt, I would buy them a small REAL snare drum. I would not mess with this one, even for fun.

I've been involved in music since I was 4 years old, so maybe I am pickier than some folks. But this thing is majorly annoying to hear. Like, smash it with a hammer and throw it away.
Of course, if you have someone you hate, you could give this to their kids. ;-)

IMHO, there is more value in this one to get it for decoration, and hand-paint the drums with really nice paint, and put a glitter finish on them. Then set them on a shelf to look nice.

text:
Well, I wouldn't buy this one again.
Yes, it is definitely cute. However, neither cat was impressed with it.
Past the intial sniff-down that they would give anything new, there was zero interest.
We tried playing with it like a puppet, hiding it under their blankets, tossing it for a game of catch,

Ours came in a plastic bag, not in any sort of other packaging.
There was just nothing special about it - and no catnip smell. Guess this was just to be a part of a puppet show,
but I took it to be a cat toy.

Overall, extremely overpriced for what you actually get.... it's just a stuffed mouse with an opening you can
put your finger in... nothing special, and not worth the price, IMHO.

title: A few tweaks and this could be really useful and fun
text:
We have been using our MathShark for approximately two weeks now.
I reviewed the directions and tried to pop in two new AA batteries. That is where the problems started.
The battery case does not slide off - it has a flat, wide screw that holds it in place, although the battery door was also warped and looked like it might not hold the batteries in place. The screw was put in at the factory in a crooked angle, so it took trying three different screwdrivers before we could remove it to get to the battery compartment. The batteries popped in without incident, and we had the same fun getting the cover back on, with the weird angled screw.

Once that was done, we turned it on to take it for a spin. It is pretty intuitive, and honestly, the directions would almost not be needed by most people. A light flashes green if you get the right answer and red if it is wrong. You can turn off the sound effects, which is pretty much preferable at our house. It feels fairly well balanced in our adult hands, and the kids didn't seem to have much trouble with it either.

The first thing I did not like was the screen. It is TINY compared to the size of the toy. The display fonts are extremely primitive! With so many to choose from now, this reminded me of the very early-on calculators or hand held games from the 1970's. They were hard to read many times. What made it worse is that this screen is not backlit. It is part of what makes it harder to read - a gray screen with either dark gray or light black letters and numbers. The contrast was not enough. And I don't know of any kid who doesn't like lying in bed and playing games! You sure can't do this one in a dark room, because all you'll see would be the red or green light.

Our model also had a problem with the number zero. Once in a while, a great deal of pushing, like you are trying to push the number button out the bottom of the machine would result in a zero, but otherwise, it just didn't respond. So every answer that has a zero in it (and of course, there are many) will be counted as wrong. Your answers are also timed, so don't waste time with buttons that don't work, because it will just increase your game time and your frustration.

There are some good things - I promise! The kids still liked it a little bit, but when they couldn't get the zero to work, they stopped playing with it. I kept trying different levels and skills just for the mental exercise. I found it was actually a bit fun to try to figure out various levels of math problems in my head, having been used to relying on a calculator so often. There are seven math skills covered in this game: addition, subtraction, division, multiplication, fractions, decimals and percentages. Each math skill has eight levels that get progressively more difficult. Some of the levels were actually a little bit of a challenge for this "old" adult. The multiplying fractions function was a reminder of how much I'd forgotten since I didn't use it! Ha! I enjoyed the mental math and trying to get a high score, but then, I always have enjoyed any sort of computer games.

I would suggest the following changes to the manufacturer:
1) Add a backlight to the screen. Evenings while bored silly or long car rides (which can be day or night) are a great time to use this item, and it is too hard to see without an abundance of light.
2) Update the fonts used to a more legible one. It looks like I picked this up at a garage sale circa 1980.
3) Use a different screw on the back battery compartment. It didn't work well at all.

Overall, this definitely could be useful, but it is not too likely a child who has a PSP or Nintendo DS would give this much of a second glance. And with so many math games available for other gaming systems, I would think an individual handheld like this would be working overtime to make sure their item is more appealing. So, if your child doesn't have any of those other handhelds, then this would be an acceptable way to practice math skills, especially in the car. The game seems very sturdy and should survive several drops. Just test everything as soon as possible, and if you have a bad button, exchange it at your store for one that works.

title: Meh.  Best description I can give this one.
text:
Well, we all love the Scene it games, and have probably ten of the various versions.
Since we all love comedy movies, we thought this would be a natural fit for our family.

We've played it a few times now, and I'm not sure where they dug up the movies from!
I'm in my 50's, and haven't even heard of some of the movies they call "comedies".
The ones you'd think would be in there barely register a blip.

So, be prepared for a stunning lack of current comedy movies. Maybe licensing was a lot cheaper
for the uber old movies than even the ones from the 1970's. Either way, it was very disappointing,
and we haven't played it now for several months. No one was enthusiastic about what should have
been a really fun game.

title: Very broad definition of "comedy movies" in this game.
text:
We all love the Scene It games and have quite a collection of them.
When this one was finally on sale for a reasonable price, I bought it.

We eagerly opened it up and started playing. First off, there are only four game pieces, and they are a little strange.
The other problem we had with this game was the INCREDIBLY BROAD definition of "comedy".
When I hear comedy, I think of funny movies usually with at least one comedian or comedienne in the cast.
There are all kinds of movies included in here (not horror, but a lot of dramas that I don't consider to be comedies.
There were many movies that I had never even heard of before... where do they dig this stuff up from?
There are plenty of comedies from which to cull the questions and clips!

We'll keep it and try it a couple more times. We played three games the first day, and my 28-yr olds didn't know a lot of the references either. So there are a lot of fringe knowledge, LOTS of questions about things most people are not really memorizing, like who the director was (lots of director questions!), or put the movies in order of when they were released.

So, if you are a huge movie buff and pay attention to things like the names of background actors and who the directors were, you'll probably do a lot better at this game than we have. Overall, very disappointing results from what I thought would be all about only comedy movies, which is my favorite genre. I give this one a "meh" rating.

title: Plenty of fun, but needs improvements
text:
I got this for my older kids who are huge POTC fans.
I've seen most of them, so knew that I wouldn't be as good as they were, but
we played this for several hours on New Year's Eve.

First off, we have other Scene It games, and this board is too tiny to make the game
very much fun. I would highly suggest scanning the board (which is made of pirate coins
linked together to move towards the bullseye), and making your own longer version
of the board! It is truly very short! I want to expand the coins in the middle of the
game so it lasts a little longer. As is, it'll be great for kids with short attention spans.

It seemed like the majority of the clips were from POTC #2. I really thought there would be
more variety than there really was. Many of the clips seemed to repeat, even though they asked
different questions about the same clip. I dunno - seemed almost like Disney threw this together
on a tight deadline and didn't have time to finish it!

That being said, it is still a fun game to play, and I don't regret buying it (but I got it on sale).
The price most retailers charge is way too high for what you'll get, so just be aware of that.
I would have felt very ripped off if I paid full price. For some reason, the POTC franchise has decided
they are worth a small fortune, and that their fans will pay any price for any item. (For example, I'd like the POTC
Yahtzee, but not at the prices they are charging! They need to be more realistic of the value of their games.)

So, if you have POTC fans at your house, they'll definitely enjoy the game. Just know that it'll end pretty darned
quickly as is, so you might need to create your own board to make it more fun.

title: Very close to the one I had 60 years ago ...
text:
I had almost forgotten about this little loom -- I first learned how to make these potholders in the 1950s even before I started school (I was probably 5 yrs old). My brother and I spent many summers working on these and selling them around the neighborhood to augment our $0.25/week allowance. My mother taught us how to make them and kept us supplied with the loops while we came up with our own designs.

One thing I remember very clearly -- she avoided nylon loops, preferring instead cotton loops. Why? Because the nylon loops could melt at the temperatures commonly encountered when using cast iron pans and metal baking dishes in hot ovens. I retained that memory, so when I saw this kit available with cotton loops, I knew I needed to try it one more time.

The major difference I see is in the length of the "prongs" in the loom -- I recall them being a little longer. Also, the metal weaving hook was a bit longer. But other than that, the design and construction are close to what I used as a child.

The package from Amazon arrived earlier today, and I quickly put together the potholder in the photo. It took probably an hour -- perhaps a bit longer, but not much. There are enough loops for a couple of pot holders and enough colors to mix and match. Follow the directions, especially the part about finishing -- pulling one of the loops on each finished edge back over a loom peg to keep the rest of the loops on the adjacent and opposite sides from popping off the loom. Take your time with this part -- it's easy to want to hurry to finish it, but it can be a bit "fiddly."

Very happy with this -- I've already ordered additional loops in specific colors to coordinate with my kitchen colors so I can make several of these to use as potholders as well as hot pads/trivets.

title: Fun projects, a little "fiddly" ...
text:
Full disclosure: I've been doing quilling off and on since the 1970s using the "traditional" quilling tools. I've made holiday ornaments, snowflakes, greeting cards, picture frames, etc. So I'm already reasonably familiar with the concept. I was curious to see how Alex Toys had "automated" the process to make it easier for a younger generation to discover this versatile craft.

You get everything you need to make the projects shown on the box: the battery-operated "winder," the paper strips, the glue, the bases, the cards, the quilling board, the tweezers -- everything EXCEPT the batteries (you'll need to supply those yourself).

The instructions are relatively clear. Younger children (the toy is recommended for age 8+) will probably need some adult help to get started, but older kids should be fine. Feeding the paper strips is just a bit fiddly at first -- it took me a couple of tries to get everything to work properly, but after that, it was smooth sailing. The kit includes clear instructions for making the various shapes (teardrop, petal, scroll, etc.) needed to complete the projects.

This might be a good intro to quilling for creative youngsters who want to try something a little different. I like it!

title: Creamy blendable colors ...
text:
I make a lot of hand-crafted greeting cards and I like experimenting with new color products. These are an interesting addition to the Crayola line. They're very soft and blendable, plus they're water soluble. I use them "as is" to create shaded backgrounds for some of my focals. When I want a spattered background, I color onto a glass surface, then wet a paintbrush to pick up some of the color and "flick" it onto the card surface. I've also used these with stencils on card fronts -- color onto glass, then use a wet make-up sponge to pick up the color, then blot it onto the card front through the stencil. Overlap a few shades, and it makes an interesting variegated background.

These are VERY reminiscent of Faber-Castell Gelatos, but in an easier-to-use form -- a thinner stick with a twist-up core. The colors are pearlized and they come in a nice storage tin. I like them -- they definitely will be used in my card-making. Solid 4 stars.

title: High quality puzzle, hours of enjoyment ...
text:
I got into working jigsaw puzzles on a cruise with several "sea days" in a row (no port stops) -- it was a fun way to meet other puzzle-solvers and spend a pleasant afternoon. It didn't hurt that the tables with the puzzles were across from one of the lounges. ;-) Anyway, I kind of got hooked, so this was a fun one to do on my own at home.

This is not an easy puzzle -- it's not impossible but it's trickier than other 1000-piece puzzles I've worked. But with patience and careful pattern matching, you'll get there! I really enjoyed working it over about 3 days (off and on) between household chores/etc.

The colors are vibrant, and the pieces are thick enough to take some minor abuse. The photo on the box provides a guide, and the pieces are marked on the back with letters that allow you to "group" them together to make placement a little easier.

I definitely enjoyed putting this one together, and it's sparked my interest in trying more puzzles at home. After all, my next cruise isn't for another 4 months!

title: Nice creative outlet for kids -- easy to make and nice results ...
text:
What a fun kit! I've used other Shrinky Dinks products in the past to create holiday ornaments and (more recently) to make embellishments for hand-crafted greeting cards. This kit is designed to make jewelry. There's a small metal "envelope" that will hold the Shrinky Dinks after coloring/baking. I made mine in a toaster oven on non-stick foil and it worked perfectly. The shrinking process causes the color to intensify.

Several of the notes are perfect for use on my cards as they contain popular sentiments ("shine bright," "Live Laugh Love," "Live your dream," etc.). The kit comes with jewelry findings to make bracelets, necklaces, and earrings -- jump rings, chains, earring wires. You also get colored pencils which work nicely.

Recommended for children 5 and up, I'd say that's fairly accurate. Naturally, parental supervision is a good idea for younger children especially, but I can see this being quite popular especially for children in the 8-12 range. Nice product!

title: Everything is provided -- just add imagination!
text:
Takes some trial and error, especially for the amount of paint to lay down before rolling to create "swirls." Once the paint is laid down on the mat, the fun begins. Crayola provides a variety of stencils and a nice set of stencils to "shape" the swirls.

I make hand-crafted greeting cards, so my plan was to use this to create "background" prints. There are several patterned stencils that are perfect for this. Using the paints and instructions for blending, I created a blue & green "pattern" on the mat, placed the stencil over the mat, and then pressed the piece of card stock on top of the stencil so that the paint would transfer to the card through the stencil. It worked nicely. There are actually several ways to transfer paint to stickers or card stock -- that's the beauty of this kit! Use your imagination and the tools to create brilliant one-of-a-kind designs.

I'm also making stickers using the supplies provided in the kit, but I'm already getting ideas for future use. The possibilities are nearly endless. Fun for kids (8+ yrs old is recommended) and adults alike!

title: Nice refill set for the 3Doodler Start (does NOT work with the 3Doodler Create) ...
text:
First things first: There are two different popular 3Doodler pens: 3Doodler Start and 3Doodler Create. Each uses different filaments and they are NOT interchangeable. The two 3Doodler pen models use different melting temperatures: Start is cooler; Create is hot. This pack is for the 3Doodler START -- it will NOT work with 3Doodler Create! Be sure you know which 3Doodler you have.

That said -- this is a nice addition to the 3Doodler Start collection. I've been using my 3Doodler to create embellishments for paper crafts -- primarily hand-crafted greeting cards and a little scrapbooking. The emojis and symbols in this set work well in terms of size -- perfect for my cards. I use the heart and star most often, as well as the asterisk, pound sign, and ampersand. There are two packs of filaments: blue, red, green, gray and white, mint/aqua, yellow and orange. Good colors that work with a variety of color schemes.

Overall, a good refill set with the addition of the emoji/symbol DoodleBlocks. I like it!

title: Nice end result, but you'll need glue and a steady hand ...
text:
I like this, but NOT for young children. I do a lot of crafts, including thread crochet (lace and doilies) and paper crafts (greeting cards with intricate lacy accents), and I had some trouble with keeping the pieces together while wrapping the thread. I ended up gluing it together, and that worked to keep it more stable. Keep that in mind ...

The thread that comes with it is embroidery floss -- 6-strands that do have a tendency to separate, so again, it takes a fairly steady hand to get it wrapped without knotting or splitting.

However, the end result is quite nice. I chose to hang mine on the wall of my guest bathroom because the colors work with a couple of other art pieces I have there.

I would not recommend this for any child under 11 or 12 yrs old, and even then, you'll need to firmly glue the frame together and and most likely help with unrolling the embroidery floss/thread so that it doesn't not.

I struggled with the star rating for this. I ended up with 3.5 stars, but I like the end result enough to give it 4 stars: "I like it."

title: Really nice small matryoshka doll stickers ...
text:
These are small, but beautiful, stickers. There are 4 sizes of dolls: the largest doll image is barely 1 1/8" tall by almost 3/4" wide; the next size is1" tall and just under 5/8" wide; next is 3/4" by 1/2"; and the smaller doll is 5/8" by 3/8". VERY cute, great colors, and sparkly gold glitter. The colors are really wonderful: bright green, red, turquoise, dark pink/fuschia -- I'm using some of these on a few Christmas cards! There are also some small flowers that are useful as "fillers" in a card design. These are a Stickerking product, so the quality is there, too. They're not totally flat -- there's a bit of texture to them, which I also like.

Very happy with these -- will purchase again if the need arises.

title: Decent quality, decent value ....
text:
I'll admit it: I'm an adult who loves to color. I find it a great way to relax, and there are some amazing "coloring books for adults" gaining popularity these days (Johanna Basford, Angie Grace, etc.). And there are whole communities of "colorists" popping up on social media.

So naturally, I'm looking for different mediums to use when I color. I've used colored pencils and gel pens, so I figured it was time to branch out into the marker arena. Someone suggested starting with these as they're water-based rather than alcohol-based, and Amazon has them at a good price, so I got the 50-ct set.

Overall, I'm pleased. There is a good selection of colors, several shades of each, which helps to bring some variety into th mix.

What I DON'T like (and this seems to be a problem for ALL coloring mediums): the actual color of the pen/pencil/etc. almost NEVER matches the color of the cap/barrel/etc. I realize that colors will look different depending on the type a "color" of paper used as the background, but seriously, some of these are WAY off. I find myself having to make a "cheat sheet" on the paper I'm using just so I can get a clear picture of how the various colors REALLY look.

Like I said, this isn't just a problem with Crayola, but they make it a little more difficult because the pens have NO distinguishing markings on them whatsoever to designate a color number or code. I ended up putting little pieces of masking tape on each pen and numbering them myself just so I can keep the color charts coordinated.

All that aside, they work great once you figure out the colors. Colors are vibrant, and I had very little "bleed through" or feathering in an Angie Grace book. Bleed through and feathering depend a great deal on the paper used, so bear that in mind and ALWAYS test before coloring.

Overall, I like these - don't "love" them, but they're good quality water-based markers at a very good price.

title: It's OK, but there are some issues....
text:
The Beados concept is interesting: small beads that get "sticky" when wet. Place them in a little segmented tray in a design or pattern, spritz with water, let dry, and you have a little art piece. This product, the "Quick Dry Design Station" provides a little boost for the drying process -- a fan -- that is intended to shorten the time needed for your creation to dry. Sounds good, right? Welllllll ... yeah, sort of.

First, the recommended age for this is "4+." Yeah, not really. I'd say 7 or 8 -- the beads are small, and require some fairly well-developed fine motor skills to get them arranged.

Then there are the "tweezers." These don't really work all that well. I understand why they're included -- if fingers are the least bit wet, the beads will stick, so this should help with keeping beads dry. But they just don't work that well. Definitely need a redesign. I noticed that some other Beados sets include a "pen" that places a bead at a time, and that might work better. Whatever -- this set comes with tweezers, and they just don't work.

The templates that come with the set are OK -- butterfly, various animals, etc. Kinda takes the creativity out of the equation, though. Still, it's a good way to learn how to work the various components, following a template. After that, a child may be able to create their own designs, which leads to .... the beads issue.

The beads are small, and even though there are 500 of them, you'll find that it really isn't a lot. You will DEFINITELY want to get more of the beads, and they're not cheap. Do NOT get them wet -- don't let water get anywhere near them -- or you'll have a real mess.

The fan is just a fan -- it's battery powered, and even with the exposed blade, it's not powerful enough to do much damage to little fingers. It puts out a slight breeze that will help the design dry a little faster. Instructions say 15 minutes. Don't believe it. Allow a MINIMUM of 30 minutes. You may have to play with the amount of water needed to make the design stick together -- too much, and it takes for ever to dry; too little, and it doesn't stick. Definitely don't "soak" them. I found that about 6-7 "spritzes" from the included sprayer works OK.

The resulting bead "plaques" aren't very sturdy -- gentle play would be OK, but they really are fragile.

Bottom line: I'm just not sure how much "fun" this will be for an artistic child. With the technical issues (tweezers, etc.), it may be more frustrating than enjoyable. And you WILL need to invest more to get more beads. If your child wants to play with creating designs, and approaches it more from an artistic angle rather than a "let's make some toys!" angle, it might be a good choice.

title: Just OK ... nice variety of graphics, but the tools?
text:
I tested this with my iPad. The box contains the info you need to obtain the app from the App Store, and installing the app on the iPad is no problem.

You use the "stamper" tool to activate the app, which unlocks all the features and pictures available for the Paint Pack. There are NO instructions except those that pertain to the tools; nothing about the various available stencils, patterns, etc. This might be a problem, as it's not intuitively obvious what those "dimmed" images are (they're stencils), or how to use them (paint or draw on top of them, then "remove" the stencil). You do get a nice variety of pictures, and the various functions are well integrated: you can stamp on a picture, start with a blank "canvas" and add whatever stencils, stamps, or freehand drawing you want, etc. Creating your own custom colors is also not difficult. That's the good news.

Now for the not-so-good news, and the primary reasons for my 3-star review:

Within 10 minutes, the paintbrush tool was splayed and virtually useless. It's nothing more than a stylus with a bunch of plastic "bristles," and in order to get the tip close enough to the screen to register, the bristles end up bent and splayed. You lose what little precision you started with, which wasn't much. No way to see the lines of the pictures if you're coloring, no way to see what you're doing.

The "air brush" works OK, as does the stamp - the instructions are accurate, and you have some degree of control with these.

Then I decided to try the capacitive stylus that I use all the time with my iPad. It worked perfectly. I could "paint," "airbrush" and even "stamp" with the stylus. EVERY function worked with the stylus. Yes, I know the "airbrush" has two rubber "feet" and the instructions say both must be touching the screen in order for the airbrush to work -- the airbrush will work just fine with a single stylus in contact with the screen. Same with the stamp (which has 3 rubber "feet") -- just touch the provided stamp image from the collection on the left side of the screen, and then touch the screen with the stylus, and you'll get the stamped image on your drawing. What's more, my stylus has a slim tip, and I have far greater control and precision with it than I had with any of the Crayola tools.

My advice? Activate the software with the stamper, then switch to a stylus for everything else. I'm afraid that kids would be terribly frustrated with the tools included in this set. Which begs the question: is this worth the price just for the downloadable app and activation "stamp"?

Bottom line: not terribly impressed; just OK.

title: Good quality, lots of uses ...
text:
I purchase and use a lot of Inkadinkado stamps -- they're consistently high quality and the prices are quite reasonable compared to other brands.

I purchased this stamp to use for a special Christmas card for a friend who LOVES lighthouses. By careful coloring (I use Prismacolor pencils), this "beachy" scene can easily become a winter scene. I paired it with this little snowman stamp [[ASIN:B008VQ21RA Inkadinkado Wood Stamp, Snowman]] -- stamped and colored him separately, then fussy-cut him out and mounted him slightly to the right of the lighthouse using dimensional foam tabs so he looks like he's in the foreground. Turned out great! Just what I wanted.

I can also see using this for a lot of other cards, too -- encouragement, sympathy, even "thinking of you." Quite versatile!

Very happy with this.

title: Good set for the money...
text:
No, these aren't at the quality level of Prismacolor or other premium brands, but for the price, I didn't expect them to be.

What you get are 100 colored pencils that work perfectly fine for most non-professional uses. I make handcrafted greeting cards, and I just started working with stamps and ink. I use these to color the stamped images, and for that, they work great. I've been able to get vibrant reds, greens, pinks, blues, etc. by careful layering.

I did get a slightly "upscale" pencil sharpener: [[ASIN:B004F9QBGE Prismacolor Scholar Colored Pencil Sharpener (1774266)]], and it definitely helps keep these sharp without wasting half the pencil in the process.

So, I'm giving this 5 stars due to the value for money -- they perform well enough for my use, and the price is more than reasonable.

title: More than a toy ...
text:
I use this with my seniors choir to demonstrate breathing technique.

My choir is made up of 28 older singers (average age is about 85 or so), many of whom haven't sung in years or have never sung. Proper breathing is the key to proper singing, and that means breathing in so that the entire rib cage expands outward, not just the "belly."

The Hoberman sphere perfectly demonstrates this concept, as it expands in every direction. We use this in conjunction with blowing up balloons to strengthen the muscles needed to produce the best sound possible, and it works! They "get it," and I hear the difference in their sound.

This has been a great communication tool.

title: Not bad!
text:
I got these to have an .... er ... "alternative" means of communicating with my cats. They're pretty well trained, but I do occasionally need to reinforce a particular response to a less-than-optimal choice. Yelling usually has little effect; yelling combined with a little liquid reinforcement usually does the trick.

These little squirt guns pack a real punch. I can pick off a misbehaving kitty at 25' with no problem. Makes life a lot easier for sure.

Yes, there were a few "duds" in the package: out of 12 plastic squirt guns, 4 had leakage problems. Still, at this price, even getting only 8 usable pistols is quite a bargain. That's still less than a buck apiece.

title: Beautiful!
text:
I purchased this for my sister-in-law for her birthday, and it was a huge hit. She collects dragons by his artist, so this was a logical choice to add to her collection.

I was surprised at the amount of detail, especially considering the cost. The photo accurately reflects the actual color -- a gorgeous bright green w/ darker green highlights. The wings are sturdy and beautifully sculpted. The material is somewhat flexible, but not overly so. This is a quality item, with an amazing amount of detail in the scales, claws, face, and wings.

This is extremely sturdy, and due to the flexibility of the casting material, could probably withstand the handling of a child, but it's pretty enough to put on display.

title: Beautiful detail ...
text:
I purchased this for my sister-in-law for her birthday, and it was a huge hit. She collects dragons by his artist, so this was a logical choice to add to her collection.

I was surprised at the amount of detail, especially considering the cost. The photo accurately reflects the actual color -- a pale icy blue with a pearl/iridescent finish. The wings are translucent, but sturdy. The material is somewhat flexible, but not overly so. This is a quality item, with an amazing amount of detail in the scales, claws, face, and wings.

This is extremely sturdy, and due to the flexibility of the casting material, could probably withstand the handling of a child, but it's pretty enough to put on display.

A good gift choice, indeed!

title: Great little noisemaker ...
text:
I purchased two of these to use with my seniors choir -- a group of 35 singers, average age about 87. I have one of them use it as a woodblock, striking with the small included mallet; and another use it as a guiro, scraping it with the handle of the mallet. It makes quite a lot of noise for such a small item, and the size works well with older adults.

I may get another one or two of these -- they work really well with the repertoire we use, and my seniors love making noise with them

title: GREAT TOY!
text: I got this for my 5yr old. He absolutely love it. The toys are sturdy and fun to use.

title: Great product

title: Pomegranate jigs are the best!
text: Best puzzles ever made. Once you buy a Pomegranate, you will never buy anything else. They are challenging because the cuts are so close, but are the best images you will find in a puzzle. And the thickness of the puzzle is the best quality you can find! Saw one reviewer who obviously found them too challenging claiming that some pieces were missing, had pieces of the wrong size, and had too many pieces. That just makes no sense to me. Jigsaw puzzles require patience to complete, especially Pomegranates. I have bought dozens and have never had any pieces missing or extra pieces, but have been stumped many times until I got them all into their correct positions. You can't go wrong. Enjoy!

title: Puzzle lover's dream - Still loving it!
text:
Love this! Been using one of those green felt sheets and knew there had to be something better. Read one of the other reviews, and he/she must not have read the instructions. If you use the covers for the extra boards, the pieces won't move; and if you use the extra large felt piece to place on the main board when you pack it away, the same is true - no pieces move around. I find this a very useful contraption when you have cats. The pieces will also slide easily when pushed in place, but stay placed when board is at a slant. Would recommend for any puzzle fan!!! Was a lot more sturdy than I thought it would be. Very impressed!!!

Update: LOVE IT! LOVE IT! LOVE IT! One of the best purchases I have ever made! Have now put together four more puzzles since I bought it. No complaints what so ever. I've put together one "shaped" puzzle which would not fit, but all I had to do was put together pieces, and used the extra four panels, and it worked out great. I would not want a larger board, because for me, anything bigger would be too hard to hold in my lap. I use this on my chaise lounge chair while I watch TV. (I'm a multi-tasker.) I love being able to put it all away at the end of the day, and it only takes a few minutes.

GREAT PURCHASE! IF YOU LOVE JIGSAW PUZZLES, YOU WILL LOVE THIS!
